content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												This game disappointed me, it has all the elements that could make a good sniper game like setting up ambushes, scoring headshots and even the cool kill-cam, but it's hampered by the other limitations this game has starting with the AI. The AI goes beyond the typical moronic stealth soldiers if that were even possible. A common tactic you would employ is to kill an entire squad run away from where they last see you and they completely forget you even exist. The AI wouldn't have been a problem if they took splinter cells' alarm system. As for the actual stealth it's what you would expect you sneak around and shoot people with a silenced pistol. You can also kick generators to cover up the sound of your sniper rifle, how this muffles the sound of a mosin-nagant I have no idea. All in all it was a dull and boring game to play through, it did run great though I guess that's a plus.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Its like they read my review for v2 (which I was on the fence about, but ultimately couldn't recommend).  Its no longer a grindfesty turkey shoot.  It now has a fully realized stealth and relocate system.  Also, a melee takedown.  Finally.  I had a blast playing this game.  Its designed more like the older Hitman games.  Open levels, kill everyone, or kill the target only, go undetected, or go guns blazing.  My only gripe is the "realistic" bullet physics are less realistic, and more just to make the game harder.  A .306 round is not going to drop a entire yard at a hundred yards out.  Which is pretty much a CS gripe.  So, this is a recommend.

Posted: October 5, 2015
												Let's face it: the only good part of this game is the X-RAY bullet cams.The enemies are incompetent and have♥♥♥♥♥♥AI even at the highest difficulty. Especially enemy vehicles.Stealthing is literally pointless unless you want to crawl around the map with your welrod for the entire game. It's easier and more satisfying just to point and click with your rifle.The story is very poor... why even bother making a story if you're going to make it that uninspired and cold? Don't even get me started on the cliches and voice acting.You do get a little more flexibility in regards to routes to objectives and in which order you do them, which is nice, but it's not really a massive step up from the previous game. On the graphical side of things, its nothing incredible, but it certainly isn't bad by any means.Verdict: It's fun for a while then loses novelty. Do not pay full price for this game. Wait until it's on sale.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												How was this game so boring.Seriously, it felt like a chore to complete. With the bugs in the enemy AI, clipping into each other, having invisible "bulletproof" barriers around some objects, repetative gameplay, pointless customization, uninteresting 2-dimensional character, obnoxious auto-saves that could potentially screw up a playthrough of a level, a complete lack of swastikas (for a game about shooting nazis), and a bland generic story; there was little to enjoy about this game. The novelty of shooting someone in slow motion wore off quickly, and it ultimately became best to just fire a few rounds into the air at the beginning of the level and pick off all the nazis as they bumbled into each other a-la-3 stooges in a single file line towards you.I didn't try the multiplayer, maybe it was good, I wouldn't know. The single player campaign sucked.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												I just finished playing the main campaign, I dragged it out several hours mainly by my poor play,  rushing over the maps instead of being a bit more stealthy.  I was also only playing for short periods so sometimes it took me a while to finish a map. Its not the sort of game that you can't leave I was more than happy when killed just to switch it off.  Its not a bad game overall if you are looking for an arcade game. The graphics are OK but early COD looking. The sniper simulation seems poor to me. The difficulty level I played on was a step down from the top level and the bullet physics should have on been "real" but it seemed very poor & quirky. The maps are quite small so there are few opportunities for very long distance shots where maybe weather would have an efffect. There are no weather effects to indicate wind direction for example. The environmental effects are static.  A few bug fixes have come out and I'm not sure my game was patched unlike other steam games where its automatic.I bought the discounted game with an included DLC which I can't find and quite honestly I don't want to waste any more time playing it. This game had the worse publicity I've seen for a game and its full list price was too much for the content provided.  I'm going to give it a negative review since I don't want to suggest people spend money on this, not at the moment. Maybe when its in a heavily discounted sale and you want to while a way a few tired hours with not very taxing gameplay, give it ago.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Well, I can't say that I am "all happy" with the game - so I'll try to give you some of the pro's and con's. I also have to say that I have only played "campaign" on intermediate difficulty level up to mission 6 so far:Pros:- good graphics, good physical effects (wind, noise etc)- good choice of contemporary weapons with even more choice from DLCsCon:- it's not an open world. You can't climb rocks or get on top of some ridges/roofs if it's not "planned" by the producers.- the enemies are very predictable e.g. the guards follow their routine tracks, only leave them when alert. There is no backup of enemies - if you kill all in an area, you can walk openly across the squares and guards from another area will stay in their designated places (as long they don't see you). And if you are used to other games like BF3 and use your weapons well (booby traps aso) - it's not too hard do kill! NOTE: that goes at least for intermediate difficulty!- the game in this difficulty is very predictable in general: if you find e.g. an anti tank weapon - you can be sure you will need it quite soon!Conclusion: if you like sniper games AND the WW2 flair - you will appreciate the graphics. If you need a real challenge, you may be rather disappointed by above limitations.DUKE

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
Product received for free
												10-Oct-2016 : Finished main storySetup : Windows 10 64-Bit, MSI GT80-2QE Notebook, Logitech G700S MouseREVIEW :I played this on Steam Free Weekend. Beautiful graphics, good mechanics, mediocre map design, weak story and characters, bad AI. It seems the developer want this game to be stealth game, but the map design and the bad AI ruined the stealth aspect of the game. Once you get caught by an enemy (and trust me, you will get caught since your Sniper Rifle is not suppressed and the map is not big enough to snipe enemy from more than 1 km away), all other enemy in the map can spot you and hunts you down with deadly accuracy shot. In short, the single player campaign missions is a disaster. Fortunately the campaign co-op and multiplayer match is fun enough to redeem it.CONCLUSION :Recommended on sale price.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Why this game gets so much Steam community praise in spite of what Rebellion did to Ironclad perplexes me (I thought the community loved to hate ♥♥♥♥♥♥ developers?). Having said that, I genuinely did think find this game to be pretty crap, not just because of who made it. I immediately lost interest in it by the second nighttime mission, whereby I realised that the only good feature about the game was the gimmick of it being set in a bright African WW2 environment. Third person games are usually just that because they have an interesting character which the developer wants you to see throughout the game. Well the character in this game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, and also American (the US weren't even in the war when the fighting was going strong in Africa!). It should be first person so the environments have a bigger impact.The final mission was absolutely horrid and seems to abandon the stealth focus that the game has leading up to it. I had to grit my teeth to finish it and only did so because I paid for the game.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												There are just things that you'll love and hate about Sniper Elite 3The Love: The game itselfYou gotta give it to Rebellion, for reinvigorating Sniper Elite series and giving it a fresh look on SE3.The Graphic, notch it up to the highest setting your GPU can handle, and you'll see how well Rebellion texturize, placing the obscurence field for the far-distance draw and giving it the 'Dx11 feel' (aka Tesselation). Aside a few graphical bug and glitches I found, the graphic for this game is superb.The Sound/Music/Ambience, the music on this game also act as a cue whether you're being seen, found out, and engaged in a combat. Any sound generated from any object in the game are well made. And the ambience on every level, like when in night mission, you can hear the cricket and the dullness of night, is just adding more to how immersive the game is offering.The Gameplay, 3 major things on this one. The Relocate strategy, The Map, and The AI. The Relocate strategy works to make the sniper-play work more believable (like, when you do something that gives yourself out, you must leave the location a few distance, cause enemy will come to investigate that location), and also it works in tandem with how big the map is.It's 3x bigger than SEV2 map, and designed also with multiple entry and approaches in mind. You can do an objective in many ways, silently taking the enemy out, or herd them to 1 place, and blow a planted explosive at their feet. The AI also is getting more smarter on this game. The AXON AI, the new AI logic on SE3, will not giving your location to the enemy when you're found out (like in SEV2), instead, when an enemy hear/see something strange on a location, they will go to that place to check it out. If things got more heated, they will also not just swarming you out from your cover. If there is a high-ranking officer in the area, he will direct the lower rank soldier and told them to move in group, stay in cover, and taking turn firing at you or stay hidden in cover until you're going into their firing range, giving yourself more hard time to deal with the now-directed enemies.That way, every game you play could have different result based on how you want it to play out, instead with the linear map play the SEV2 offer.Now what's the Hate? The pricing of the gameI find the price of this game is quite exaggerated, considering much of its content of the game are now in DLC.Things like more weapon, more challenge mission, more multiplayer maps are being placed on priced DLC.The fact that this game is priced on $50, and to get all the game's content to extend this game playtime, you must buy another DLC, is just not right with me (and maybe most gamer out there). Maybe if this game are on the $30 range, the DLC is quite the right move for the developer (they need money, making game is awfully expensive).That said, I say it's a good choice for getting Sniper Elite 3, it's the best semi-realistic sniper-simulation game out there (outclasssing it's own predecessor). But if you have something that made you hesitate to buy this game (like the one explained on the Hate section), wait for a discount, then grab the game and also all the DLC if you can.

number of helpful: 27 of 50 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												It's safe to say that this game will be one of my top candidates for game of the year.Let me first say that I am a fan of this series. Sniper Elite V2 despite it's flaws is one of my favorite games of the last "generation". I love the idea of being a sniper and going behind enemy lines to kill Nazis. The moment Sniper Elite 3 was announced I was immediately excited and I pre-ordered it the first day it was made available on Steam.With that caveat out of the way, Sniper Elite 3 is essentially a beefed up V2 in a brand new setting. Like V2, you're not playing this game because of the story. This game is all about fun, sneaking around, and killing Nazis as effortlessly as possible. What makes Sniper Elite 3 superior to its predecessor is how it takes the mechanics I was first introduced to in V2 and ramps it up and improves the gameplay in almost every respect.Let's start with the basic improvements. For me, there are two absolute standouts. The first that comes to mind is AI. While it's not perfect, it's much more fine tuned. It's now possible to kill in a variety of ways, from up close an personal melee kills, sneaking around with a silenced pistol, and of course the core of the game, sniping. In V2, once you took a shot the enemy was aware of your presence, where you were, and they don't let up until they're dead or you're dead. Now, relocating is imperative and allow to "reset" should you be discovered to go back to playing stealthily. I do think the AI could be further improved on even more, but I find that I have that gripe in a lot of games.  In SE3, it's now possible to use sound to your advantage which presents itself in a variety of ways including a howitzer being fired, a faulty generator, and even the weather + there are others. A prompt at the top of the screen comes up when the sound is masking your shot. This allows the player to stealth large portions of, if not the entire level. The second massive improvement comes with the way you approach each mission. One of the biggest knocks on V2 is that it was very linear, and you were forced to play a certain way. Not anymore. The maps in SE3 are humongous and allow the player to approach a mission anyway they choose. Earlier today, I was on the 3rd mission and by the time I completed it, I realized I had spent well over 90 minutes exploring, trying to find the collectibles (still missed some) and killing Nazis on this one map alone. This improvement alone increases the re-playability of the game.The improved and more detailed Kill Cam is also a welcome inclusion as nothing beats an enemies head exploding after a perfectly placed head shot.Technically, I think the game is very tight. The Africa setting is rendered extremely well and the graphics are very strong. I also find that the sound design is good and it's nice to hear the German army actually speak German. I've encountered very minimal bugs which undoubtedly will be patched before long.There are a variety of different game modes right out of the box including the return of Survival (a horde mode) which can be played solo or with a friend only for now (hope they allow randoms again like in V2), and the return of co-op modes like Overwatch, which allow one player to be the spotter and one player to be the sniper. There's also the addition of multiplayer modes including the requisite team deathmatch. I have yet to explore most of the other modes at the time of this review, and will return once I have gotten a feel for them. I did however spend an hour trying Solo Survival, and I know that will add to the replay value the further along that I go.I feel that this game is exactly what a sequel should be. Change locations, improve the technical details of the game, and add some new, and very welcome elements that truly make it unique. I would love to see V2 patched with a lot of the SE3 additions, which is obviously a pipe dream, but the changes are so well done that it would be awesome to see.All in all this is an excellent game that I'm excited to play even more. I know that I will still be playing Sniper Elite 3 for the foreseeable future and eagerly am anticipating what else is coming down the pipe that will add to the game even further.8/10

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												Stealth, long range precision distance kills and deadly melee takedowns. A major improvement from the 1st and 2nd iterations of the series. This truly defines what a stealth sniping game is all about. Graphics: 10/10Outstanding by any means. The level of detail is something to behold, I have not seen this much level in detail in a game for so long. This one looks absolutely gorgeous even at low-medium settings. There are also a lot of graphics options to choose from to suit your needs and to maximise your experience.Storyline: 7/10You have to stop Germany from building a Super Tank that could potentially be used to change the tide of war. Other than that, that is the only ‘story’ you will get from this game as it isn’t really a story heavy game and it wasn’t made to be one. You’re buying this for the sniping experience, not much for the story. Sound: 9/10They nailed it. The sound of the rifle, the enemies around you and even your own footsteps can be heard in great detail. Nothing more can be said of how this game sounds. You hear what you’re supposed to hear, nothing else. Gameplay: 9/10This goes without saying but, you can snipe your enemies with skill and precision from a distance or get up close and personal and perform melee takedowns. Setting up traps and distractions can also be very fun if carefully planned and laid out. Oh, and I almost forgot...there are “sounds” in the game which can mask rifle shots which makes for quiet long distance shots; pretty impressive if you ask me. The overall game performed nice and smooth with no significant frame drops to report. Price: 5/10Priced at £39.99 for the base game, it is a little too much for the amount of gameplay hours you’re probably going to have. So, I suggest waiting until it goes on sale to pick it up.

Product received for free
												I played this game during the "free weekend".Completed the campaign, about ~10-12 hours long if you like to explore a bit.I would not recommend to buy this game at full price, but at a large discount it's a decent buy.Good things:-Graphics-Satisfying feel of sniping the enemies.-Action overall is pretty fun.-Gun sounds.Bad things:-Very repetitive-The same mission locations (the only difference is some are at night, some are at day)-The locations are like a copy/paste of the "Splinter Cell: Blacklist" first missions, it just felt very similar.-No need to use automatic guns, you either snipe people or pop them with the silenced pistol.-Lackluster gun customizations. -The same non-mission related objectives in all the missions: collect some war diaries, find several sniper nests, do a long shot, collect some cards.-Stupid enemy AI.-Forgettable story.

												Sniper Elite 3 aka ShootNazisintheBalls 3 is actually a pretty good game, it has everything you want from a good sniper-game. If you want wide open levels,many different types of weaponry and equipment,a good variety in mission goals and a 2 player coop, this is the perfect game for you.Probably the series most famous feature are the killcams.The killcam in the first part was a cinematic killcam, which showed the point of impact very detailed.The Killcam in the second part took it one step further, now you could watch the bullet ripping it's way through the targets flesh, bones and organs.In the third  part they added the muscle tissue,veins and all that stuff. content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												If There's anything ive learned from the Sniper Elite Franchise is that sniper's in WW2 had amazing stories. Not having really any knowledge or interest in the past Sniper Elite games *Cough* Sniper Elite V2 *Cough* I was convinced by my friend to pick it up and it was on sale so I decided to pick it up and so far it's amazing. The graphics are beyond beautiful, And the gameplay get's better and better as I play, I just absolutly love this  new feature where loud noises and destractions will mask your shots. You play as Karl Fairburne, a sniper working for the British Intellegence. As you play you will unlock new sniper's, machine gun's, pistol's, and more items to arm yourself with. How the maps are designed are incredable and fun to play on. Coop is the icing on the cake. Playing this with friends is so much fun. There are 8 maps  (Not including DLC) but are so much fun and long. The only downsides are the Assassinate Hitler mission is a DLC, and multiplayer is not that good. So overall this game deserves a 9.5/10

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Got this game for free with a promotion when I bought my new GPU, and I was not disappointed.A worthy sequel of Sniper Elite V2, the game is set in the North African Campaign, from June 1940 to May 1943 between Libyan and Egyptian deserts.Nothing to say about the bullet balistics that are, as always, perfectly made: if you want to place a long shot you'll need to take account of wind, gravity and also your own heartbeat.The locations are really well made, with lots of tactical opportunities: need to hide that body? Try tossing it in that well.Before every mission, you can customize your loadout with custom parts for your rifle, anti-personal and anti-tank landmines, tripmines, TNT charges, bandages, medkits, grenades and more. You can also customize your crosshairs.The enemy is not really smart, even at maximum difficulty: if they spot a body, they'll start searching, but I think they give up the searches too easily. They also walk too often into your traps; if you want to get rid of a patrol, silent kill one of them and place a landmine/tripmine near them, lure them by tossing a stone to make noise, and bam, you're done.The bad part? TOO. MUCH. DLCs.Seriously.4 rifles, 3 SMGs, 3 pistols. Want more? Buy the DLC!Two horde maps. Want more? Buy the DLC!Rebellion, that's not the way to do.Vote: 8/10, since it's on sale give it a shot (no pun intended).

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
Product received for free
												I've been playing during Free Play but as many reviews have said already, the game is awfully linear. Linear games can be a lot of fun; the Last of Us comes to mind. This one though is very repetative. At 80% off, I'd say it's good value but I couldn't imagine paying any more than that (~$11 CDN). Graphics are nice. Mechanics are so-so. There seem to be some bugs preventing me from shooting when I clearly have a shot without obstruction infront of me, magazine is full, breathing is right, but it just wont shoot. I have to remove my eye from the scope, adjust my position and line-up the shot again before it will allow me to shoot. It's happened on more than a couple of occasions. Slow-mo kill shots become old very quickly and I skip the vast majority of them. The idea that you are to stealth in this game seems silly -perhaps I haven't mastered the mix of run and hide? Replayability seems low but co-op seems to be a good idea (haven't tried it yet). All in all, for 10 bucks, why not? Full price though? Not a chance.[Update]My friends seem to be experiencing the issue with shooting as well. For some reason, there are times where you "pull the trigger" and it just won't shoot and there seems to be no rhyme or reason to it. I've now tried co-op and it is fantastic. I cannot see my self playing single player anymore and just sticking wtih campaign co-op. Full disclosure, I do prefer to play with friends, I play few games single player. At $11 for co-op, I'd say it's a steal. Great co-op game! (Also, didn't receive it for free as I ended up buying it after the Free Play while it was on sale but cannot update that part of the review.)

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Having played all the games in the series, I'd have to say the ratings are as follows: 3>1>2. 1 was incredible for the time and a unique playing experience with many huge levels to experiment in. On the highest difficulties it was a demanding experience that rewarded patience, good planning, and accuracy. 2 was a step down from 1 in the level design department,  having far too many close quarter battles in claustrophobic small levels. It's still a great 7/10 game, but it has issues. 3 is where they really hit the sweet spot, combining technical improvements over the last two games and fantastic level design. Although the amount of levels may seem sparse, each level is it's own massive sniper sandbox, allowing many numerous different approaches to each objective. The campaign took me 9 hours to beat on Sniper Elite difficulty and I only really did 50%ish of the secondary objectives, not to mention all the little collectibles scattered about each mission. In short, I highly recommend you check out Sniper Elite 3.

After buying this game, check market, theres a lot more that will give you a better experience. personally, this one stands a glorified game series that went from good/decent to a strict fail and is definitly on the bottom of development.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												Sniper Elite 3 aka ShootNazisintheBalls 3 is actually a pretty good game, it has everything you want from a good sniper-game. If you want wide open levels,many different types of weaponry and equipment,a good variety in mission goals and a 2 player coop, this is the perfect game for you.Probably the series most famous feature are the killcams.The killcam in the first part was a cinematic killcam, which showed the point of impact very detailed.The Killcam in the second part took it one step further, now you could watch the bullet ripping it's way through the targets flesh, bones and organs.In the third  part they added the muscle tissue,veins and all that stuff. This make's Sniper Elite 3  one of the most graphic games out there.Just buy it and see for yourself.PS:  Hitler only has one ball

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												A fun stealth-shooter with iconic cinematic gore-porn. Sneak up on enemy bases, study their movements and either eliminate or avoid - your call. Knife or silenced pistol for up close, a variety of scoped rifles for far away, a few other guns for everything in-between, and even some anti-tank stuff.It's military-esque, but don't expect a military simulator - the 3rd person perspective should tip you off to that right away. But it's a fun shooter with lots of achievements and gameplay that you can do however you want. Not too much hand-holding, but was designed primarily for slow and sneaky.Maps/chapters are big, varied, and well-done, but there aren't as many as I thought there would be - in other words, the game feels a bit short and inconclusive. Expect to complete it in 8-10 hours or so. Has some replay value - owing to the huge maps and open gameplay choice. The DLC was obviously left out of the main game at launch so they could squeeze more money out of you for it. Some physics bugs (clipping, invisible walls, etc.) in spots can be annoying, but not game-breaking. Plays very well with keyboard and mouse.

												Love this game, the graphics and attention to detail really adds to the immersion of the game for the buildings, terrain ect,., the lighting in this is incredible, with a duel core and decent graphics card good ram i have my game almost maxed out, i dont get any issues with graphics, game runs fine.What would be really cool is if the game is if some things were more destructable.The AI in it are a bit updated vs Sniper Elite V2 but they could use a bit more work in terms of what they do overall their alot better, they could use more dialog tho, better tactics although i am only playing on marksmen so guess i will have to try the other levels and see if there is any difference.I wish the game had a map editor so you can create maps for the challenges, i play the sp challenges alot but find they are limited in terms of where you can go, why? Your talking about sniping here, long range shooting, anyways some other things like the weapon sounds, including the new weapons from the DLC about all sound the same, sometimes when you shoot it sounds like a ...cannon going off, or idk hard to describe not bad just saying.Sound wise for a sniper sim if it were should have the guns sounding close to their real counterparts, They could do alot more for this game to make it more simulated in some areas.The real fun parts and best part is the bullet cam, as well as putting down mines, trip mines, even doing stealth attacks where you either knife the guy or fight with him.I definately recomend this game, if you played V2 which i also reccomend and still play, you'll like this, theres quite a number of achievements to earn too. Posted: February 10, 2016
												This game lets you make very important choises that really impact gameplay. well really there's only one "should I try and use cover?". Cover, as we all know from other games, is great when you're trying to stealth passed enemies or for soaking up those bullets from them once you finally get seen, but Sniper Elite 3 takes things further then that. The cover even blocks your bullets, despite the fact that when you look through the scope it looks like you have a perfect shot, BUT WAIT there's more. When in cover, say a watch tower designed to be sniped from, the cover will help you decide to go down a more peacful path by not letting you shoot at all. I MEAN HOW GREAT IS THAT?!?! This game is like sex, by that I simply mean it ♥♥♥♥s you.3===D/10 Bite the pillow this game's going dry.Also the dev is sueing a better company for no good reason, simply because they don't want their names attached to a product that actually works.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												The only good thing about this game is the bulletcam. Watching your enemies testicles explode or faces get just destroyed is extremely amusing. You'd think it'd get old fast but I enjoyed it through the entire campaign. Which brings us to the first issue.The campaign is way too short. I completed it in a night.The weapon selection and customization options are lacking, and some rifles that are unlocked at the very start of the game are just better than others in every possible way. It's pointless to have a bunch of unlocked rifles where some of them are just♥♥♥♥♥♥The detection system for enemies is glitchy, especially vehichles and muffled sounds from planes.Any time you damage a vehichle, even if its with a landmine and you are on the other side of the map, it knows exactly where you are instantly and you suddenly get "attacking" status and all enemies know where you are. Plus any time it loses sight of you and you come back into it's field of vision it sees you within a fraction of a second, turns the cannon absurdly fast (think like one of those weird garrysmod videos) and fires a shot. All within about one second.Planes fly overhead on most missions periodically providing sound cover for your shots, but while you can hear the plane flying by with the same noise and volume every time, you only get sound cover from it some of the time. Also on at least one of the levels the planes don't seem to fly overhead if you're stationary. Only when moving around the map making them useless to help you snipe which is their entire purpose.The game is full of invisible walls, cliffs that should be easily scalable but are instead impassable AND the terrain is unrealistic. So like, the worst of both worlds.Many of the good sniping points, hell even most of them, are inaccessible by stealth until you've taken out half or more of the enemies that you'd want to be in the sniping point to take out. I don't feel so much like a sniper in this game as a grunt.There are an unrealistic number of explosives EVERYWHERE. EVERYTHING EXPLODES. And yet somehow the explosives are almost never in a useful spot.In the difficulty screen they try to boast that there's a difficulty level for sniping purists. Enemies that work together to root you out and hunt you down, and gravity affecting bullet trajectories. First of all, what about wind? you're gonna put gravity in but not wind? But the real problem is the enemies on the highest difficulty are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The AI is average at best. They don't work together to hunt you down, they occassionally walk in a straight line towards your position, always hitting traps and almost always by themselves.I've never been flanked by enemies trying to trap me, I've never had enemies avoid or disarm my traps after they saw their buddy get blown up by the first one, or despite the fact that the trap is an anti tank mine sitting in plain sight. And much of the time I can sit in one position, pick off two enemies, wait for the detection bar to go down, pick of two more, and repeat till all enemies are dead, even though they heard where my shot came from, they never come to investigate.Overall the game was fun but very disappointing for something that supposedly was aiming to be difficult and realistic. If you're going to buy it, buy it for the gimmick, the bulletcam. It's so ♥♥♥♥ing funny.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												After really enjoying Sniper Elite V2 I was excited for this next game in the series. It seemed like more of the same, and that's certainly a good thing...right?In this case some of the same elements were present: the bullet cam, the weapons, the physics, not to mention the awful, forgettable story. But the changes they made resulted in a much worse experience overall.Foremost was the level design. In 2 the levels were admittedly linear, but they had long sight lines to encourage gratiutous sniping, which is the name of the game after all. And they also included a wide variety of objectives. Here in 3 every level follows the same arena-style circular motif with short lines and lots of cramped spaces - presumably to make them easier to re-use as multiplayer maps. The problem is that this pushes the player to use stealth and close range combat as the primary means to engage the enemy. In a game that's supposed to be about sniping this is incredibly annoying.Beyond that, the flow of each level is exactly the same: infiltrate, explore, then take out the vehicles at the end. The fact that every single "boss" in the game comes in the form of nearly identical armored vehicles is pretty unforgivable. It's so repetitive that I got bored less than halfway through the campaign. I knew what was coming around every corner my first time through. It reeks of laziness.The campaign also feels more serious, which is not the direction the writers should have gone with this series. And while I appreciate the change of setting to Africa, that combined with the story make the stakes feel like they're not high at all, lacking comic relief to boot. The new setting also forces set pieces that could exist in any time period - there's almost nothing tying the environments to World War II.The one area where the game actually did better was the add-ons. The bonus missions feel much closer to what I want from a Sniper Elite game. And the multiplayer is surprisingly fun and balanced once you get over the learning curve.When the mechanics are identical and the story doesn't matter then the level design becomes paramount, and that's the biggest area they failed in the campaign. Sniper Elite 3 kept enough of the parts from the previous games to feel familiar, but not enough to feel fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												This review is based solely on the Multiplayer part of the game, since the Singleplayer part is just generic mediocre entertainment, like a Val Kilmer movie or something like that. And to be perfectly honest.. The only thing I actually enjoy in this game is the "killcam" which can be extremely satisfying and rewarding.That said, I don't find much else to praise in this 3rd part of the series. It's as if they solely concentrated on making the killcam more detailed, gory and with slightly ridiculous sounds of bones breaking etc. The models look rushed, the textures are mediocre at best and the shading and lighting is appalling (with some infuriatingly unavoidable big sunglare. Then comes the gameplay.. Which feels as clunky and sad as a rushed B game for the PS2. Annoying "cover" mechanics, some very solid shrubbery (not all the vegetation is solid though), insultingly few maps and customization and a clunky and buggy "aim assist".So to sum up:For the price of 45.99euros I had expected at least a finished and polished product fit for the PCs of 2014. Not a game I feel could've been made for the PS2 or at the release of the PS3. I honestly feel a bit robbed having paid so much money for a game that Clearly isn't finished. Oh and don't think I intentionally tried to find faults and errors in this release. I actually So wanted it to be good (and I still think it has tremendous potential), and for 2 days I've kept trying to come up with excuses for the glaring faults, be they aesthetic or gameplay, but I find it insulting to the gaming community when they charge 45.99euros for this. Had it been 15eu or something down that line I could've shrugged it off more easily. But no, this is robbery and I do not recommend people to buy this game yet. Maybe in a month or 2 when they hopefully have fixed the bugs and maybe made some extra maps.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												Sniper Elite 3 is a very enjoyable 3rd person sniper game in which you play as Karl Fairburne. An American sniper. The game takes place throughout Africa from airfields to bases built into mountains.Visually, the game is very well presented. I was able to play it maxed out with a constant 60FPS with v-sync off (It would seem that it’s capped). Although, even with my 1060, the frame rate would sometimes drop into the low 40s and high 30s and given this game is over 2 years old, I would put this down to poor optimisation of what is clearly meant for consoles. Not only did I have frame rate issues, but screen tearing was also rife with basic movements tearing the screen like an angry child ripping up a piece of artwork he made a mistake on. However, the game was still playable and very enjoyable throughout with no crashes after just under 10 hours. Gameplay is also very enjoyable. If you have played any other Sniper Elite game, you understand the ins and outs of it. The sniping is fun and it is always enjoyable to shoot a German or Italian and watch the bullet to travel through the air and shatter their eyeball and penetrate their brain, very satisfying stuff. Missions, of which there are around 4, (wide open maps with optional side missions) are a bit repetitive and you will probably never do the side missions unless you want the 100% complete achievement. Although you will probably expect a sniper game to revolve around sniping, it does get very tiring very quickly and I sometimes found myself getting out my Thompson and gunning down a few Germans just to change it up a bit. The machine guns in this game were obviously meant to be a second thought if you alert the base as you can only carry 2 magazines of ammo unless you carry an MP40 (and even in this case you only get around 2-3 bullets from looting an enemy corpse). If you were to get this game, just keep in mind that you probably won’t be playing it non-stop until you finish as it does get very repetitive and sniping does become boring after gunning down your 50th Nazi. The AI is not too bad, sometimes you can walk right in from of them and they won’t see you, other times they can see you hiding behind a box. A lot more work could’ve been done here that unfortunately wasn’t.  The story is very poor. You basically set out the kill some generic Nazi Commander with your missions being to collect information in order to find out where he is and when he will be there. I didn’t really pay attention to it, I was enjoying sneaking around and shoving knives into a bad guy’s ear (yes that is one of the silent kill animations). But the story in this game is basically non-existent apart from a few lines of dialogue from the main protagonist during loading screens (that’s really the only place you find out what you’re doing and why). Now for the price. At the time of writing this (05/10/2016) the game is £39.99 which is absolutely ridiculous. This game, brand new on release, is only worth about £20 in my opinion. I purchased this game off Ebay for £8 and for that it was very enjoyable. I think this is just a clear example of one of those games that Steam have just forgotten to lower the price but while the game remains at this price, I would find it elsewhere for much cheaper. If you pay any more than £10, you paid too much for this. Overall, it is a very enjoyable if a bit short (10 hours on the hardest difficulty until I got to credits) but way too expensive on steam. You will have a good time watching Germans trip over trip mines or walk into anti-personal mines, failing that, you will also enjoy getting a perfect shot and watching your targets testicles pop so long as you don’t pay too much. TribalHARRY.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												How do I even review this masterpiece!? Best sniper game on the market for sure and the Kill Hitler DLC is simply...The best...DLC...EVER! Kill Hitler, change history, if only this guy was real. Ha. Well let's get on shall we? I had really high expectations regarding this game and they broke every single one of them, whatever went wrong in Sniper Elite v2 like the AI for example has been fixed in SE3. I also like how Stealth is even more important here as it was on SEV2, if you decided to go Rambo, don't. Seriously, don't. You're gonna get ganked and if you're not fast enough, you're dead. I like the Close Quarters takedowns you can pull off and the revamped kill cam is just hilarious to see sometimes, I did notice some bugs where for example the bullet came out of my barrel in reverse, directed at me, but ended up showing where I hit my target, doesn't happen too often but I think this is something Rebellion should look into. The best thing about this game are the realistic mechanics a real life sniper would come in contact with, you can't just point your crosshair at someone's head and expect a instant headshot on him, you really have to take the distance of the shot and the wind in consideration and adjust your aim accordingly. Great game, if you're into sniping, buy this..Immidiately. For me personally, it is the best game I bought this year.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												Review for single player campaign:I got this game for free when purchasing a new graphics card. I left it a while as I had played the second game a little at a friend's house and wasn't in a rush for it. When the time came to play it I found the start of the game quite exciting and it rapidly gained my interest as I sunk the first few hours into the game. The story line I found kind of generic but interesting enough. No real relatable characters or depth. This however was not the point of the game at least in my opinion. The kill camera for perfectly aimed shots was fun at first but by the time I had reached the half way point in the game I had turned them off completely. The game play however was enthralling throughout the campaign. I spent hours on a mission taking it as slowly as possible and trying to be "the perfect sniper", crawling through the grass on my stomach trying to reach the next point of cover to scope out a target area. Making my way around the map working out the best position for attacks and covering my rifle fire with ambient noises. When there were none, sneaking into the area and executing people from behind. I had a lot of fun. Overall if you are looking for a first/third person shooter with stealth aspects and at least some level of control in choosing how you went about your objectives this could be the game for you. If you are looking for a sandbox environment you will be disappointed, while not having a linear game play progression style most areas only give you a couple of options on where to stage an attack from with only a couple of combat styles for those few choices. 7/10Review for co-op and multiplayer:Will be added in the future.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Edit: i have not totaly reversed my judgment of the game as it still needs bug fixes, but, I have played an awfull lot of it and still keep comming to play it.After all sniping can be fun.So I am recommending it , but with a few caveats.But Still;This game needs to be patched to fix some horrible game ruining featues /glithes /bugs.1) Using Binoculars in this game is a horrible affair.Textures fade in and out from low to high and vice versa.It is the worst depth of field I have ever seen and totaly ruins the gameplay.2) There seem to be invisible walls or something for a lot of shots.Had a lovely shot lined up, scoped to the max, empty lung headshot, Clear view, nothing in my way.My bullet hit ??? about 100m out and that was that. 5 shots, same thing.3) In one level I was spotted through a wall AND Shot dead.another level I was spotted by guys 10m bellow me in a bunker.4) the sound masking works when it wants to work, you can hear the LOUD sound and sometimes it will display the Icon for a masked shot, other times you just have to leg it.5) tanks and other vehicles can see you behind them, Tried sneaking up on a tank from behind. Turret was forward, so no way he can see me. Well all went great till I planted dynamite, then the turret swung around and followed me as I ran around the tank, so close that I could have keyed it. So then I was stuck, move away from the hull and get blasted.6) the Ai is crap / brilliant / accurate and lousy all at the same time.They give up too easily. They don't notice the guy in front just got his head blown off. They hang around in the open searching, etc.7) there is autosave AND a load last save option as well as a Load game option. I have yet to figure out how to access the load game feature as I presumed it was for loading an earlier autosave. nope.8) The controls are a mess, fell off a cliff trying to back my character up, he turned in a circle and fell.you can sprint in straight lines but forget about turning as the sensitivity on the mouse drops way off.Easiest way is sprint, stop,turn sprint.The mouse contols vary between the in game map, the main screen and the character movement and the aiming. Some feel a bit floaty, others sharp. mouse smoothing was off and mouse acceleration was off.The option to reduce mouse lag had no effect at all.9) The campaign missions all follow the same patern.Get to a location, shoot/find something, etc.. and when you think you've finished, enter the boss match, some overwhelming force you must deal with or something to protect.10) The view distances with the scopes is nothing compared to Sniper Elite.If you want to kill at 500m+ range, then good luck.This game thrilled me for 1 hour then just bored / annoyed me for the rest.If you played S.E v2 this is not much of an improvement..If you just want to snipe, then by all means get this.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I'd say it's worse than V2, which was free a month or so ago. The guns are stupid unrealistic, you still can't dial in distances on scopes, the wind blows your bullet a meter off target on a 100m shot (in a canyon, with a gentle breeze), way too much short range (<100m) fighting and way too little real sniping. Read the Wikipedia article, sniping is about shooting from so far away enemies can't return fire or even hear your gunshot. I have a feeling the maps are so small to accomodate consoles. The COD-esque ranks and loadouts suck as well (and Alpha Bravo Charlie Delta in WWII? Have the devs never seen a WWII movie? It should be Able Baker Charlie Dog.) The entire reason sniping games exist is difficult, satisfying kills, not mowing down hundreds of guys. There are plenty of better shooters and better stealth games out there, but no sniping games as good as this could have been.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Sniper Elite 3 (SE3) takes place in Northern Africa, which is a theatre often neglected in WWII games. Usually games focus on the European Theatre (western and/or eastern fronts) and slightly less often, the Pacific Theatre. That's a nice change and presents a locale that hasn't been overused. Something I also like about North Africa is that despite it being mostly a rocky desert, there is still plenty of environmental plant life to make the scenary appear not quite as depressing. I remember in Sniper Elite v2 (SEv2) thinking that the constant use of broken and blasted buildings became quite tiring, despite it being accurate for the location. SE3 brings in slight RPG aspects, in that your equipment has various stats. The rifles in particular are interesting because you can greatly modify them using parts you find as you play. That said, many of the "better" rifles and pistols are only available in DLC packages, but it's entirely possible to play through the whole game and do exceptionally well without ever spending a dime on any DLC. The overall game mechanics are similar to SEv2. On easier difficutly levels you don't have to account for gravity (bullet drop) or wind, and pressing the focus button (the default is "E") enhances your zoom and slows down time. You have a limited amount of focus and if you expend it before firing, you'll zoom out and time will resume as normal. Fortunately, focus replenishes by itself.Head shots are preferable to body shots, although I've managed to kill enemies after hitting them in the leg. You can perforate major blood vessels and organs (seen through an x-ray view when hitting the enemy), which the game acknowledges, but I don't know if that really makes a difference as far as killing them goes. I believe the game really just takes into account general location damage, so a high velocity shot to the abdomen might result in a kill, regardless of it tearing apart the intestines or kidneys. Remaining undetected is a major part of SE3. You can do this by using your sidearm (assuming you've taken either the Welrod or the HDM, both of which have suppressors attached to them), stabbing an unsuspecting enemy in the back, or using noise to hide your sniper shots. Noise cover can range from artillery fire to PA announcements to sabotaging a generator. Although you have a secondary weapon (which can be anything from a Thompson submachine gun to a Panzerschrek, which is essentially a rocket launcher), using it will undoubtedly cause a ton of noise, thereby attracting scores of enemy soldiers who will overwhelm you on anything except the lowest difficultly level. Even then, it's still fairly easy to die, so it's best to avoid that scenario entirely if at all possible. Unlike SEv2, enemies DO NOT suddenly pop up out of nowhere. Reinforcements can be called in (usually through scripted events), but you won't have to deal with inching forward after clearing an area only to come upon a soldier who materialized out of thin air. The campaign takes place over eight long missions. In contrast to SEv2, which relied entirely on checkpoints, SE3 allows you to save whenever and wherever you wish using manual saves and quicksaves. Some players might find this "cheap" or refer to it as "save scumming," but to me it's simply a matter of convenience, which lets me play for as long or as little as I choose.Multiplayer takes the form of PvP and PvE Co-op. In PvP multiplayer, you play on a team and fight other players, whereas in PvE Co-op, its you and your teammate against the AI. In co-op, you have three choices:1. Play through the entire campaign in co-op mode.2. Play specific downloaded missions.3. Play unique asymetric assignments, where one player has a sniper rifle and a pistol, and the other player has a pistol, secondary weapon (such as an MP-40), and binoculars. A shooting range has also been added as an extra single player mode, which lets you practice with all the weapons, including explosives. No matter how good SE3 is, there are some problems. When playing co-op, the campaign missions only use temporary checkpoint saves (as opposed to the "save anywhere" method in single player), which can make for some exceptionally long game times. These checkpoints only last for the duration of the session, so if you quit, you'll have to start over the beginning of the mission.This has been a problem for my wife and me, as although we enjoy SE3, we don't always feel like spending four hours or so on one mission. It would be nice if the game at least saved the progress of the mission on the host's machine and allowed the players to continue where they left off.The asymetric missions almost always include a "horde mode" component, where you have to defend against waves upon waves of enemies. In a game like SE3, where stealth and not being noticed is generally considered important, this seems very out-of-place and if you're not ready for it, quite jarring as well. Something else that's of general annoyance is the way a weapon's stats are presented. Using a combination of white, yellow, and red bars to denote standard, improved, and reduced stats (when comparing other weapons to your currently armed weapon), understanding the bars can be unclear, at least at first. I would've preferred numbers instead of nondescript bars, but it's not a big deal overall. In the end, would I recommend Sniper Elite 3? Absolutely. If you're the least bit interested in playing a sniper and World War II, there's no reason for me to not recommend this game.

												Sniper Elite 3 (SE3) is a big step down from SE2. This game is clearly unfinished & filled with problems. At first I was disappointed that you don't get your shooting percentage but after seeing that at times it can take 3 to 9 shots to kill a guy I understood why.  If you don't press "E" when using your scope the shots can bounce off like he's covered from head to toe in metal. One very frustrating problem is when you try to shoot over or in between rails & your shots just hit the rail even if your barrel is past the rail. There are also graphic problems & the only way to resolve them is to exit out of the game then come back in. Trust me that you don't want to pay full price for this game, I think the game is worth about $20.00 so wait until it comes on sale. I expected so much more out of SE3 after playing SE2. It would be nice if you had your shot percentage (after they fix the shooting) & also the amount of head shot kills. I haven't tried the MP but seeing they never did make it work in SE2 I don't expect MP will work very well in SE3 as well.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												More technical difficulties than a state school server room. For the want of a new release after V2 for the same reasons, I can't see how there's been any improvement on the first. While the gameplay sets in after a couple of missions, there's a feel for how the Welrod and rifle pair up, but the last save point becomes the most used feature. The list of issues can be accredited to jittery animations, almost like they know you're watching, and the age old know-it-all AI. Take down an alerted enemy, the only of several who know where you are, and the rest come running to your exact position, never having seen you. There also seems to be a bug in the way concealed gunfire works in conjunction with a canon or dodgy stationary motor. Countless times the AI went on alert after shooting during the covering noise, making it confusing to know the outcome of options. AI enjoyed screwing up multiple attempts by detecting my movement through walls, and I don't mean on account of running, but by their mesh sifting through the wall and somehow seeing me. A WTF moment including being shot by a soldier who was shooting me, as he hung suspended in a wall (see screenshots). Other soldiers fired through the corners of buildings, without head-view of my position. A run through the underground/basement tunnel of a hill somehow alerted soldiers on the summit, as they cascaded down to my position. The animations even included unnatural movements making well set up rifling utterly clumsy. Most rifle nests also come with no gunfire cover, so it's game on if you want to use them. The upside of all this bumbling around is cracking the idiodic AI in the melon with a big calibre rifle. After all, they embody the frustrations with clunky algorithms well enough to feel a sense of satisfaction popping a pair of eyes out. It works really well on the level of infuriating the player into enough of a rage to really want to put a thousand pounds of shrapnel into the back of someone's centre mass. The problem is, and many times over, this often won't kill the target, as they fumble forward, about face, and successfully put machine gun bullets in your head from the hip a good 70 metres off. Lovely. :/

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Unambitious and far too safe, Sniper Elite 3 is in general a reskin of Sniper Elite V2.Carrying over the same mechanics and realistic ballistics that defined the previous game, Sniper Elite 3 does little to differentiate itself and keeps itself within a safe little boundary that prevents it from being a full-fledged sequel and instead feels like the developers were too frightened to tip-toe out of that proverbial boundary and kept everying generally the same. Primarily the differences between the two games are as follows: A new and exotic setting in North Africa, new weapons and tools to utilize, the ability to customize enemy AI and ballistics to suit your preferred playstyle and a new story. To expand on why these features don't contribute a lot to the game and make it stand out: The setting, while personally I enjoy, is not something to base too much emphasis on, you dedicate DLCs around new locations, not a whole new game, so while the desert setting is pleasant it also fails to accomplish the ultimate goal of making Sniper Elite 3 stand out as it's own title, and it's actually the most notable difference. The new weapons and loadout options I don't care for, because almost every unlockable weapon and/or part are all underwhelming, offering a minor benefit at the cost of what I feel are major costs in damage or stability. So I generally use the same loadout in every mission since the Garand is by far the best option for the game and serves to every need I require, making the loadout customization completely untouched. Difficulty adjustment is actually the factor that has drawn me into the game despite my disappointment at the previous titles, both previous games had some of the most rudimentary and challenge-destroying AI possible and ruined a large portion of both games, I'm glad to say that the AI in Sniper Elite 3 is at least challenging and rewarding to play against. Another new factor in the AI department is a feature called "Relocate" in which enemies will discern your location and begin to attack if you continue to fire from the same area, but Relocate gives you the option to move out of the area and begin the hunt anew. While sounding good in theory Relocate can be easily exploited wherein the player fires once or twice from one location before moving out to another, then repeating the process. Finally, the story. Once again you play as Karl Fairburne, the same tired and uninteresting protagonist from the previous games. Karl is the same as before, he's boring, 2-dimensional and leaves no impact on the player, offering nothing to the experience other than to be the guy you play as but immediately forget after beating the game. Which is a huge reason why I'm disappointed with the game, we've got this exotic and beautiful new setting, why do we still have this blank sheet of paper to play as? Tell me it wouldn't be great if we could play as someone new, like a British soldier since a good part of the game's plot involves working for British Intelligence, it would make more sense to have a soldier of British background and provide an opportunity to make Sniper Elite 3 stand out more. But no, the developers I think are trying to make Karl a staple and recognizeable video game protagonist akin to Gordon Freeman or Lara Croft, which with his blank-slate personality is just impossible. The overall story as well is underwhelming and paper-thin, leaves no impact and is entirely forgettable.Now it may sound like I'm saying that Sniper Elite 3 is a bad game, but this is not entirely true. On the contrary actually, I like the game and I do have fun when I'm playing it. If it was released as a stand-alone title or as the first in it's series I'd be praising it without remorse, however as a sequel it falls short and doesn't do much to differentiate itself from the last game. Sniper Elite V2 wasn't a bad game, but it did have a lot of flaws that kept it from gaining alot of recognition, Rebellion had the opportunity to take these issues into account when designing the new game but instead worked on a clone with a different coat of paint. I know it sounds like I'm beating a dead horse when I say that it's practically the same as V2 but I feel that this is a valid and legitimate issue that is holding the series back from its full potential. So to give this review a more positive outlook; Sniper Elite 3's setting is as previously mentioned absolutely gorgeous, unique and alot of fun to explore and observe. This may be a biased viewpoint since I've personally always had a fondness for desert landscapes but it is true, the levels are beautifully rendered and at the same time well optimized, giving me an average of 60 FPS on high settings. Combat interfaces are rewarding and fun to experiment with, rewarding patience and execution with unerring proficiency. Setting up traps to fortify a sniper nest or roaming the battlefield collecting intelligence on enemy patrol routes and locations is a highly rewarding experience with a combat system that gives the player positive feedback. The infamous X-Ray kill cams make a return and add a lot to the satisfying payoff of lining up the perfect shot, but just like the last game the novelty of them gets tiring pretty quickly and I've found myself to lowering them to almost non-existent after a while. Sniper Elite 3 is also host to a large series of experience-breaking bugs. The killcams often don't work as they're supposed to, sometimes cutting out early and others just giving the player a view of a blurry area while the sound effects play. The AI also has it's garbage moments, for example: Vehicles have incredible perception and can pin-point your exact location with little effort, which makes no sense seeing how the operators field of vision is limited by the vehicles armor. And yet when shot it will immediately know exactly where you are in an instant where human enemies take a moment to determine where you are even if they've been physically shot. It's like the vehicles in the game all have a synthetic nervous system that is hardwired to the driver, so he can find you miliseconds after you try and take it out.Now that you've read this far into the review, be advised that the following portion WILL CONTAIN SPOILERS. READ AHEAD AT YOUR OWN RISK.If you have the attention span to actually notice the weak storyline, you'll learn that the game revolves around uncovering intelligence on the construction of a German super tank, the Ratte being built under the ambitious supervision of a high-ranking general named Vahlen. What I feel Rebellion should have done with the story is give more spotlight time on Vahlen throughout the game, establish him more as the biggest threat to the player all the while never giving them the chance to strike at him until the final level. What happened instead was Vahlen being mentioned vaguely throughout the campaign in letters and enemy dialogue, and being thrown in at the last minute of the final level. What's worse is that the player doesn't even get the satisfaction of killing him yourself. He's injured in one cutscene and then shot point-blank in the head in another cutscene, which ultimately leads up to a very disappointing ending where Karl walks off into the horizon giving a bland monologue about killing people. With a terrible and easy-to-forget protagonist, an antagonist that you aren't even given the chance to hate and a forgettable and weak storyline, Sniper Elite 3 leaves so very much to be admired.All things considered: I'm afraid that I'd have to give Sniper Elite 3 a thumbs down, it had potential but failed to live up and expand its horizon beyond the limiting confines of its mediocre predecessors. The gameplay, while fun does gets tiring after a while, the story is quick to be forgotten, the mechanics are unambitious and added nothing new to the series and in all it literally is just a clone of Sniper Elite V2.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												I keep seeing negative reviews for this game, saying that this game shouldn't be played for some reason or another. Granted, there are definitely some flaws, but there are also a lot upsides to this game. I keep seeing negative comments about how this game only has 4 rifles. I personally don't see why this is an issue. Yes, if you want more, you need to buy DLC, but I have never felt the need to. The 4 rifles cover all your bases. A long range, slow firing rifle, a short range, faster firing rifle, a medium range rifle with a better scope and so forth. There is also a good amount of pistols, including the default silenced pistol. I have never felt that this is limiting me in anyway. Maybe if you're used to CoD, or FarCry, you might think there aren't that many guns, but for this game, mainly being a sniping based game, I feel like it works. The other negative comment I see a lot is that there are several DLCs already out for it. I can see why that might be a little bit annoying, but I wouldn't let it turn you away from this game. As stated prior, I have never felt the need to buy any other guns, so that already opts out the gun DLCs. As far as other DLCs, I havn't played them. I have not needed to. The campaign has kept me quite sated, and the other modes, as well as competetive online, also keep you busy.Everything in the game works well as well. I have not encountered anything game breaking or that unappealing. If the game is too easy, there is a mode that makes all bullet ballistics and physics 100% realistic, which believe me, makes the game MUCH harder. The AI wasn't anything spectacular, but nothing horrible either; it got the job done. I feel like there was a good mix of sniping and stealth, combined with "going loud" action. Voice acting was a little cheesy, but it fits the theme and time of the game. I have had a blast playing through this campaign with friends co-op, and doing the spotter/sniper missions co-op. Decent replay value with all the modes and online, plus it's fun to try and play at higher difficulties. Overall I'd give this game a 7/10. Worth the money, and I still come back to it often enough.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Sniper Elite 3 is the highly anticipated entry in the Sniper Elite franchise. I am a big fan of this series, and I even enjoyed the somewhat repetitive Zombie Army titles. I was hoping for an enjoyable romp through a slightly larger world with improvements to the stealth and sniping mechanics. Rebellion certainly doesn't disappoint.You play as Karl Fairburne, a US Sniper dropped into Africa during World War II to combat the Afrika Korps stationed there. You'll navigate through gorgeous rendered canyons, valleys and deserts to complete your objectives, and Rebellion has done an excellent job in the graphics department. I was never once disappointed by the visuals in this game, and was wowed at every opportunity.The levels are also quite large, and there are also optional objectives to complete during a main mission. These include tasks such as assassinating a visiting colonel, sabotaging a German fuel depot and eliminating enemy tanks. While not particularly original, these objectives are fun to complete and provide a nice XP boost.Gameplay has a number of mechanics designed to create a good sniper game. You have items such as stones and flint that you can use to distract enemy soldiers, as well as a silenced pistol to kill enemies discreetly. You can loot these corpses for items before moving their corpse to another location, which is a relatively unseen feature in modern shooters. Another stealth mechanic is the ability to create noise with other items so you can fire your rifle without being detected.On the subject of sniper mechanics, this game excels. The gory x-ray kills are back, and you can witness your bullet shattering bones and puncturing organs in fantastic HD glory. Bullet drop and wind speeds are an added factor to sniping, which makes each kill that more satisfying.Despite being a solid game overrall, Sniper Elite 3 has a number of flaws. Enemy AI is fairly inconsistent, and will go from spotting you easily to being blind to your movements and visible corpses. The amount of bugs in this game is quite baffling, but most have been fixed due to frequent patches. Not a game breaker, but definitely frustrating if you're not a fan of bugs and glitches.Overall, Sniper Elite 3 is a solid entry in a solid series. It improves over its predecessor, but still has the dull story and characters retained in the series. Despite this, I'd recommend this game for the huge levels and enjoyable mechanics. 8 / 10

												Sniper elite 3 is one of the most intricately designed games I’ve played it is just simply amazing from gameplay to graphics through and through. However I have only minor concerns here’s what I like and what I concern (keep in mind I have only played the game on sniper elite difficulty and easier difficulties tampers with AI intelligence and bullet physics also I haven’t finished the game yet I’m about maybe halfway through)•	Realistic bullet physics very well done also all snipers are completely different in stats and it can be very fun experimenting which one suits your play style and sniping skill (sniper elite / authentic difficulties) •	Extremely smart AI (sniper elite / authentic difficulties)•	Huge maps exploring is a must and just feels right very fruitful as well  •	Many different ways to handle objectives (however on sniper elite difficulty  going in guns blazing partially suicidal its possible but very hard, authentic difficulty you might as well just shoot yourself) •	wide-ranging  modifications and upgrades for each rifle •	well-designed all maps are unique from one another and a pass or bridge could have another hidden 5 different ways to cross for either a stealthy approach or a ambush point to gain an upper hand in a firefight•	gunplay is great if any then minor unnoticed problems•	bullet time allows you to see were your bullet hit and the damage it is doing its gruesomely attractive and extremely satisfying to watch for example your bullet ripping through the eye and peeling off the top of the skull of a Nazi officer or castrating a Nazi, yes there are testicle shots ashamed their no achievement for getting one   Concerns o	not many weapons only 4 snipers 4 submachine guns 3 pistols and the first pistol “welrod” is the best pistol the other 2 are trash o	the story and some voice acting is skeletal (:my opinion: but who f*ck cares gameplay is great and it give you an excuse to shoot Nazis) o	if you want more maps and guns you have to buy the dlc’sOverall 9.5/10

												I liked this game a lot, like its predecessors Sniper Elite and Sniper Elite V2. The interface makes it a bit more easy - not as hard as previous versions on hardest level. Added a nice knifing stealth kill. What I really miss is the possibility to shoot grenades off the belt of German soldiers -- making them explode. Certainly I did expect more maps included; the extra DLC maps are few and relatively expensive. AND of course, as it is situated in Africa, I would have LOVED if they would have thrown in some lions, snakes, crockodiles and such attacking you unexpectedly as you were sneaking up to your enemies. Or some herds of wildebeasts to startle and stampede over your targets (or at least creating a diversion). I would like a bit better AI: when you find a dead comrade in your camp, you dont just look out for enemies for 30 secs but would comb out the area I'd think. But nice graphics and very playable interface and controls. Overall a very fun game to play if you like sniping, stealth and tactics.

I like it, but maybe they could introduce something different.Gameplay (8/10)Pretty much the same, i do like the fact that u can customize ur wepons further here and also and exp system is very good. Though the last saves are pretty annoying, (save from time to time urself.) I do like the exp system tho i dont see its point but still cool to have.Graphics (10/10)Freaking stunning, it is incredibly detailed, animations are very smooth and the background and little details make this game visually stunning. Overall: Get it when it is on sale.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												A Gorgeous game that takes place in Africa during World War II. Third person action, great stealth mechanics, even with total control over movement, and FINALLY, a game which has mastered the art of sniping. However, the story is, IN MY OPIONION (my review) average. Alot of people will argue with me, and say it is awsome, with espionage and such, but it is rather straight forward and predicatble. Still, this game is so fun that the story dosent matter much. I have not tried multiplayer, but guessing from my experience with Elite V2, (the predeccesor), I'm Guessing it requires a lot of patience, skill, and has alot of camping (duh). Overall, a large improvement in every aspect over V2, even in story, (I dont like either, but at least this one is slightly realistic. Russians stealling the plans to some rocket in V2 is just dumb.) so I give this game a 8.75/10

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												I liked this game a lot, like its predecessors Sniper Elite and Sniper Elite V2. The interface makes it a bit more easy - not as hard as previous versions on hardest level. Added a nice knifing stealth kill. What I really miss is the possibility to shoot grenades off the belt of German soldiers -- making them explode. Certainly I did expect more maps included; the extra DLC maps are few and relatively expensive. AND of course, as it is situated in Africa, I would have LOVED if they would have thrown in some lions, snakes, crockodiles and such attacking you unexpectedly as you were sneaking up to your enemies. Or some herds of wildebeasts to startle and stampede over your targets (or at least creating a diversion). I would like a bit better AI: when you find a dead comrade in your camp, you dont just look out for enemies for 30 secs but would comb out the area I'd think. But nice graphics and very playable interface and controls. Overall a very fun game to play if you like sniping, stealth and tactics.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												*This may seem quite negative, but playing multiplayer changed the review into a recommendation... barely.Lets get down to it.For the price asked, is this game worth it? Lets go back a step and ask a more important question; Is this a game?Well, a game is something you have fun interacting with. It challenges you and provides entertainment. Sniper Elite 3 is definitely challenging and it can be fun, so lets pencil in a "yes" for the question of is this a game. Now, is it worth the price?No. Definitely not (Unless you want to go purely multiplayer - see below). I'll admit I have not played the previous 2 iterations of Sniper Elite, but they cannot have been worse than this. The graphics are pretty and the xray cam can be amusing and fun, but this is counteracted by the clunky mechanics, often horrible animations, weak AI and general lack of polish on the entire thing. Still, the xray cam shots are amusing.Level design feels like limited paths with varying chances of getting pounced on by several enemies and shot into paste. The AI is perculiar to say the least. Enemies finding a dead body will become "suspicious" for a short time... then forget there is a problem. The noise-masking you can do by using noisy environmental objects to hide your rifle noises is a good idea, but was not executed as well as it could have been.UPDATE:After a bit more time with the game, I found that the multiplayer co-op aspect of it greatly increases the level of fun you can have with the game. Co-ordinating your shots with someone else or covering each other while sneaking around giving surprise stabs to the neck is fun and makes things worth your time. Single player might not be fantastic, but multiplayer makes up for it.
