content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												Heyyo,So I just beat the campaign to Sniper Elite 3 (played on Sniper Elite difficulty) and it was pretty good! The sniper gameplay is much like Sniper Elite V2 with a fresh coat of paint... and wow is it a lovely coat of paint. The graphics are phenomenal and the game runs so damn good too! They really brought the Afrika Korps to life in this game. You'll see beautifully rendered Panzer III and IV tanks, including the British Matilda... there's also the Tiger I Tank that looks badass.The sound effects are the next improvement... wow I love the sounds of the guns in this game. The MP 40 especially. The way it sounds when it fires or reloads is fantastic! I also love that creepy sound the game makes when enemy snipers are trying to get a bead on you or when enemies go into combat mode... kinda reminds me of 70's horror movie sound effects when the killer is sneaking up on you... freaks me right out heh.I guess I can talk about the sniper gunplay next since it's the main part of the game heh... well? It's handled quite nicely and the x-ray mode is improved over the second game in the series... but it's odd, sometimes the bullet cam gets confused and flies at full speed instead of slowing down or fails to recognize a double kill (can happen if enemies are too close together) but the rest of it works great. The controls are just about perfect... I say just about as I wish it had a button to toggle what shoulder you're looking over. it's annoying when trying to come around some corners if you're not hugging said corner to try and force the camera to pan shoulders...The campaign is actually quite the nice length as it took me 16.2 hours to beat so I feel it's actually a really nice length to it. The environments are varied and they don't feel the same which is nice since of course the gameplay options are a bit limited.. snipe, run away and return and snipe seems to work the best. It does feel like a bit of a gameplay flaw that enemies can't figure out where you are if you quickly run away and return to the same spot while they're in caution mode (yellow compass warning)... because if I ran away and came back in real life? They'd still figure out I'm in the same spot kind-of thing.Which leads me into AI... they're decent in this game but they give up WAYYY too easily. I mean... I just sniped two of your comrades! They're dead near you!!! What do you mean you're already returning to normal patrol? Aren't you worried that you're probably next? Hahaha.... So sometimes when I feel like a challenge? I'd place anti-personel mines at the bottom of stairs or ladders leading to me and set up... and then they never charge me. Instead they just keep tossing grenades at me... so that sucked. I'd recommend to other players doing the singleplayer to just set up traps in front and below where you want to snipe in positions you figure where the enemies will try and toss grenades from. I've also had AI run off bridges to their deaths and also run into fire from a left over explosion and get themselves killed haha... so yeah, AI isn't the best in this game and if I did a future playthrough I'd definitely do the hardest difficulty.So? 16.2 hours for the singleplayer campaign and I got it on a weekend sale. I'd definitely recommend it on those sales for the singleplayer. Tbh I don't really see myself doing multiplayer as I'm not the best at sniping haha so I'll keep my multiplayer gameplay to the likes of World of Tanks. So? If you enjoy

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												I pre-purchsed Sniper Elite 3 as I had already bought Sniper Elite 2 + all the DLC's for SE2 and thoroughly enjoyed every minute of the entire package. I'd gone through the campaign several times, mostly at Marksman level (my personal favourite - I enjoy lining the diamond up for a shot), but also at Sniper Elite, mostly for the achievement. Sniper Elite 2, after hundreds of hours playing time is still a game I like to 'dip back into'; play a particular level in a different way, setting myself a particular challenge or go for an obscure achievement, or just play for the extra points and pure pleasure of the graphics and settings. This cannot be said for all campaign WWII shooters, some can get very predictable and can only be played in a certain way which you will realise after only a couple of plays through, so I'm really pleased to be in the Sniper Elite camp. Sniper Elite 3 proved to be even more superior in all aspects than SE2. Once again, hundreds of hours into the game and I am still looking forward to playing each mission over and over again. Still finding areas of the maps I havent explored, and after maybe 5 times through I can honestly say each time has been a completely different experience. The only thing that will hold you back as you sneak through the North African settings will be your own imaginative methods and skills. The cam-kills never get dull for me, and being able to retain stealth while I systematically silence and destroy airfields/factory's/gun emplacements etc is truly satisfying. One (constructive) criticism is the subdued enemy response to my attacks. While it really is real fun to creep through missions sniping with sound cover or silently downing enemies as I tag and find them, sometimes it seems the realism is lost as after a short period of 'alertness', comrades of the dead just seem to resign themselves to the fact that the garrison (or whatever it is) they are stationed at is slowly but surely being annihilated. There is no heightened sense of alarm. It is possible to hide bodies, which is an amazing feature, but what with the enemy not seeming to care too much, after a minute or so, that another of their comrades has been found dead, there wasn't a great deal of incentive to use it for me. I won't comment on the MP as I haven't played it enough to appreciate it, but definitely from what I have played its all thumbs up from me. Atmospheric, tense and immersive, and definitely a game you will go back to over and over again. More Sniper Elite (4?) please : -)

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												Pros+ Visually pleasing+ Good UI+ Decent if forgettable voice-work and sound design+ Satisfying sniping mechanics on higher difficulty settingCons- Levels filled with invisible walls- AI is very stupid- Repetative gameplayAt the end of the day, this is not a terrible game. However, the sniper based play is at odds with the stealth. The result is AI that hears booming shots, sees their friends go down, and yet makes no real effort to find the shooter or otherwise respond in any reasonable way.The game feels very dated, and aside from its visuals, it really belongs to 2004 more than 2014. I guess it could be a decent enough distraction if you're really lost for something to play, but there are just way better games out there for the same money.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												The thing I like most about this game is how it's improved since V2. The controls all feel very familiar,  that is to say there's nothing too different about the layout of what-does-what and it's responsive on top of it, even though I still find it a little annoying that you have to take cover behind a crotch-high wall before you can vault over it instead of.. well, -just- vaulting over it. Or perhaps I'm just doing it wrong.You can definitely see that a lot of the effort has gone into the the gory, slow-mo shots where you can see, in close and loving detail, a bullet drill right the way through a poor sod's head, splattering brains, blood and bone everywhere. The only nit-pick I have with it though [honestly, I don't mean to sound like a grim and creepy fellow with this] is that after watching my bullet bore it's way through a man's face and exit with what appears like it should have left a wound the size of a grapefruit, there appears to be little damage to the individual. I've clearly surgically removed several unfortunate blokes' faces with a conservative amount of bullets but when I trot on over to the corpse, those eyes I've taken great care to get rid of are still there. No halves of skull missing or gaping craters where you would assume there'd be a considerable exit wound; kind of makes the gorey, attention to detail of the anatomy side of things feel a little bit half-arsed. But I'll overlook that as it probably is a rather large amount of work to do.Despite this, the game is great fun. Skulking around in the shadows, being able to plan a method of attack from any and all directions instead of the usual, linear path a game can normally give you. Shadows even affect how concealed you are and there are even some lanterns that can be shot to cast a bit more shadow at that; a feature I though V2 desperately needed. The whole relocation mechanic is great as well; forcing you to stay on your toes and not get too comfy in one spot. It adds a bit more of a pace to the game and add a tad more realism to the experience in that a sniper can only take so many shots from the same location, even though realistically a sniper can wait in one spot for days defacating in their pants for even just one good shot.But in all; I do have a couple of huge gripes with this game:We'll start with the length of the game; eight levels stardard just isn't enough for a full price, hyped up title like this. If you know what you're doing you can fly through those levels in less than a day and it's never a good sign when your players get the the end and sigh saying "Is that all?". Also, not including DLC [which I'll get to], four rifles, maching guns and pistols. Really? This game is called -Sniper Elite- and there's only four rifles? What annoys me even more is that the protagonist clearly has a Kar98 on his back in the box art and not only is it not in the game; it's not even DLC. So to even have a nice veriety of guns and even have just more than one thing to do in the survival mode and multiplayer modes you -have- to buy the DLC that came out on day one with the game [and others, now that there's another out I believe]. Why not just include it in the full game? That seems a bit money-grubby to me and like Rebellion has done the fans a bit of a disservice there just make a bit of extra pocket money.However despite the length of the game and the seemingly greedy intentions of having a very limited arsenal included, it's a very solid and very fun game. Definitely worth a go. But to be fair; I wish I didn't spend as much as I did on it for the amount of game I actually got on purchase. A 3.5/5 from me- Matt

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												For me, personally:PRO:-Good looking game. Textures are off in some places but that's not a huge deal.-It can get very brutal in a high difficulty.-They learned after SE:v2 and improved a lot of things.-Weapons and how you can have a tailored to you variety. (mostly)-I wouldn't say it's a long game, but it's not really short either. Nice middle ground.-A lot of the time, movements are predictable - but there has been the odd time where I have been caught out and seen.-I have came across only 1 bug - ONE - which was easily resolved by restarting the level. This can be a con, but to me it's not.-Cinematics are short and sweet, but can be skipped anyway.CON:-Sound and sound masking seem to still be quite off and unrealistic.-Night missions; enemies can see like it's day, but for someone like me that uses low contrast for ambiance can't see them.-Although I said weapons can be tailored, it's still a choice between this, that or the other. You can't be a run and gun person effeciently.-I feel the scope and the aim helper are off sometimes. The helper said I had a hit, I shoot, and the bullet flies above or past them. (Note: I had this very few times. This could be just a mechanic to not make it a faceroll? No idea)-Killed a guard, someone found the body. That someone just looks around, shrugs their shoulders and carries on patrol. No alarms or searching the area or at least gave the corpse a cup of tea. Nope, like nothing happened.-You get seen or heard from a shot and get chased to where you were last. Relocate, get an all clear and everyone just goes back to normal... again like nothing happened. This universe plays devilish tricks, I tell ye.That's all I can think of for now. Do I think the price tag is worth the game? drop the price to £29.99 and then yes, it would be VERY worth the money I would think.TL;DR: IMO, a very good game, but has it's offsets by AI and sound masking.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Another entry in the Sniper Elite franchise. And boy, it's a great one.Story: The story might not feel very deep, but it works.Graphics: The graphics are absolutely fantastic. Look at the beautiful enviroments of North Africa. Definatively Scenery Porn (look it up on Tv tropes). The character models also look very good. Even on low settings it's impressive.Gameplay: The gameplay is in my opinion, improved a bit from V2. While regenerating health still exists, now it will only fill up to a certain point of your lifebar, anymore injuries than that will require bandages or medpacks to heal. The shooting still works very nice. One flaw though is that they removed the cover system from V2 (press Q), but so far it hasn't been affecting me that much. The A.I shows some improvement from V2, they will now react more to suspicious stuff, like gunfire and dead bodies. If you kill a soldier, they will start searching for you, and will find you eventually unless you relocate. You can also occasionally find weapon parts or upgrades for your weapons which can be used to modify your weapons.Music: The music is, like V2, epic and well made. You can even occasionally hear songs from V2 on the radios in some missions.Overall, Sniper Elite 3 is worth the money. If you liked V2, you will enjoy 3 as well.Also for the last, it has trading cards, and the X-Ray killcams are just absolutely AWESOME (shooting an enemy in some parts of the head will even DESTROY parts of the cranium).9/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Sniper elite 3 is definetly better than its predecessor. HUge improvements. This game is definetly 1 of my favorite stealth games.The challenge scales brilliantly now. I played it on hard and found it just so much better. You can focus on going 100% stealth now, without those "must fight" situations..You have bonus objectives that in conjunction with the improved stealth mechanics and difficulty scaling, makes the game not only more interesting but bigger, fuller. In all seriousness this game might not have "dishonored" story or characters, but it definetly has better stealth and reason to map explore.1 of my favorite points of this game in comparison with other stealth games, are the kills and how enjoyable they are. Reminds of "Tenchu". It will make you want to scour the map just for extra kills. The stealth and gadget system is vastly improved and you will have to use everysingle 1 of them eventually. They also added more rpg elements and extra things like shooting range to the game. Havent tried multiplayer, but what i can tell you, is that, as a single player experience this is possibly 1 of the best stealth games out there.I recommend it, not only to stealth fans, but to shooting game fans and eventhough its not a classic fps, it offers what most do with extra uniqueness. Waiting for the game!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												Let's get first things first: Sniper Elite 3 is not a realistic sniping game. It's a third person shooter with stealth elements. The plot is as follows: Nazis have secret weapon and America Man needs to destroy it.Most of the marketing focuses around "celebrated rifle ballistics" which is really stretching the things on offer. The series is already over 10 years old and when it was new, this might have been true. What you have here is a sniping system that has many elements: Sights wobble, bullets drop and are effected by the wind. Also the player needs to hold breath to focus the shots. Wind is the only thing that is not also present in most of modern shooters so it's not that special. It takes a bit of skill and luck to hit enemies while timing shots with sounds of passing planes etc. It's a nice spice to the standard gameplay but with the level design and mission objectives that Sniper Elite has, it is in no way realistic.While there are many elements to the sniping, some key things are missing. Most notable is penetration. Bullets won't pass even through wooden fences! Kills at 20 meters are much more common than they should be and a "long distance" kill is awarded at over some 170 meters. This doesn't feel realistic at all.Maps are fairly large and kind of open. A single map might have 3 objectives, which are all in their own areas such as a depot or a village. In these areas it's possible to move about quite freely, but the areas are divided from each other by canyons and other tight corridors. So it's not open world but a series of open "arenas". Often the map design feels really forced and make no real-world sense. This also ensures that you'll never have more than about 300 meters of space from end to end. For a shooter it's ok, but for a sniping game it's not.Sniper Elite 3 puts a lot of emphasis on sneaking and it is possible to sneak for really long parts of the levels, silently taking out guards, dragging bodies, luring with noise, setting traps etc. Usually things go badly at some point and after that it's just your regular shooter. Even on the hardest (custom) difficulty, the player can take a load of bullets with ease and the game doesn't punish for going guns blazing. No mission failures, no overwhelming enemies, nothing. Maybe some of the achievements are lost but that's it. This is by far the biggest weakness because there is no need to stay silent. It really doesn't matter if you get caught and some 30 infantry are alerted. It's too easy and also faster to kill them the loud way. Hardest difficulty on offer (authentic) removes saving and sounds like tedium the game. As it's hardly suitable for co-op, this review is based on custom difficulty with hardest AI and ballistic realism. Enemy AI is seriously flawed in that they don't coordinate with eachother in any way. They will spot corpses and hear gunshots etc. but they work as individuals. Also they will forget strange sounds and such almost immediately and never raise a base-wide alarm. Relocation system is a key selling point in Sniper Elite 3 but it's kind of silly. If spotted a radius of 50 meters appears around the last known location of the player. Run out of that area and your relocation is instantly succesful and enemies no longer no where you are. If you for example get spotted in a bunker with a 50 meter long corridor with and exits, just run to the other end and you are hidden againMost of the levels end in a showdown against a tank which of course appears without infantry support and must be destroyed with conveniently available mines or rocket launchers. This is always a mission objective and you can't sneak away from the area. In some missions the player takes spot in a sniper nest and covers someones exit. These kinds of missions usually end with over a 100 kills. And of course maps are littered with red barrels and canisters that explode from a single bullet. Sniper Elite 3 clearly is just a standard third person shooter. As a standard shooter Sniper Elite 3 is actually ok. Main campaing can be played in co-op and it's forgettable but fun. In co-op the main campaing can be completed in less than 7 hours. Season pass adds some more, but overall the game is really short. It is possible to coordinate with a parther but its not necessary. There are unscriped moments where best action is to eliminate two guards with simultaneous shooting and setting those up feels great. After that it's usually just shooty-shooty but as such it gets the job done. I would not recommend Sniper Elite 3 for someone who seeks realistic gameplay. Neither would i recommend it for full price. It's ok for mindless co-op shooting when it's on sale. The emphasis is on the mindless, since there is nothing special to see here. It brings nothing new to the genre and is mostly as generic as possible.

content:
Posted: February 13
												First of all, the game is great fun. There are enough detailed reviews of that. But it wasnt very enjoyable for me. My System includes an i7 6700k and a gtx 1080 and i had a huge amount of crashes and performance problems. The performance is just horrible. I played early access and ubisoft games with a better perfomance. In the 6 hours i played ths game so far i had easily 30 crashes at random occasions. It crashed when i loaded the game, quicksaved, when there was alot going on on the screen, when there was nothing going on and i just watched at the horizon, i had stuttering while steam and afterburner showed me 250 fps and then it crashed, vsync didnt help, changing all the other graphicsettings didnt help. I tried every "fix" that i could find. Even the error messages werent consistent. It saddens me because i really loved the first and the second entry to the series and also that i payed money for that game. It really sucks but this is probably the last rebellion game i will ever buy and i cant recommend this game to anyone. Only if you buy it over steam ( unlike me ) you can try it and get a refund in case you got the same problems. I had the first crash like 10 minutes into the first mission fyi. Thanks for reading and good luck.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Singleplayer: Taking into account that this is a game about sneaking and sniping, I still find it pretty boring. It's basically a prettier Sniper Elite II, with a hint of gun customization. Multiplayer: It is the antithesis of Call of Duty. Depending on who you ask (me), even if you dislike run-and-gun shooters on some level, this doesn't actually make this game any more appealing.But it does have good bullet physics and killcams, and - let's face it - this is probably why you're even thinking about buying this in the first place.6/10. Even if you're interested in it now while it's at full price, I'd advise you to wait till it's $15. Because IMHO, that's what it's worth.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												As much as I enjoyed playing Sniper Elite V2, I cannot say that I had a good time playing Sniper Elite III. It looks very unfinished and the bugs that I ran into demolished my entire gameplay experience. The game itself looks really nice graphics wise, running on a GTX 770. The maps are much larger and open than in its predecessor but you still have to struggle with the annoying spawn mechanics, whereas you can take a look at an obvious spot for an enemy sniper (like a tower) and spot nobody. And while you approach it BOOM there he is, spawned out of nowhere as you are getting closer. The shooting distances are often very short and the game feels more like a close-quarter hide-and-seek game for kids.I should have saved the 40€ I paid when it was on pre-order. A real disappointment.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I've got my money's worth from this game. This is something I made sure of especially as I originally had purchased a copy from a vender that was not steam, and therefore was deemed "stolen" by Rebellion and revoked. But I won't turn this review into a rant about that, I paid my £40 and have played Sniper Elite 3 now for about 40 odd hours. I've completed the game on Sniper Elite mode. I've completed it on Authentic mode. I've collected all the collectables. Completed all the bonus objectives. I've completed the DLC and obtained all the achievements from that. I've got (at the time of writing) 54/61 achievements for SE3 and I'm almost at the point of a perfect game. Once there I think I won't bother with this game again. You see, I was a massive, MASSIVE sniper elite and sniper elite v2 fan. I also loved the v2 zombie nazi DLC/standalone's too (although truth be told I haven't yet finished both). I was really looking forward to SE3. I had been following its progression for a while and tried not to get too excited because I didn't want to spoil the joy of release day. When its release day finally came around (and all the BS of getting an actual copy aside) the initial 10 minutes of the game were brilliant! It looked great, colours were vibrant and lush. The sound was crisp and map design was classic. I went through the tutorial really enjoying what I was doing, sniping through bino's, melee kills, finding collectables etc.Then when I moved onto the next mission I started noticing issues almost immediately. Invisible barriers blocking shots, AI shooting through walls at me, AI spotting from waaaay over the other side of the map, BULLETPROOF grass and bushes, AI that suddenly spawned in areas you had previously cleared, extremely slow trigger response on SMG's and sniper rifles, falling through the map when proning near walls, standard stuff that should have been found and fixed during development by Rebellions QA. These issues continued to plague my experience throughout the game. I should have stopped then and there and got a refund due to a grossly unfinished product, but I continued on because I really wanted to enjoy it being a massive fan of the franchise. I eventually committed too much time that stopping would have annoyed me just as much as all the issues and bugs I was experiencing, so I just decided to grin and bear it and try to 100% the game and then "put i on the shelf" and never think about it again. I don't really know if Rebellion will ever really fix all the problems this game currently has because there are so many. I work for a major games publisher and know that when we've released a title in the past, and it's had a bunch of issues with it, we've had to decide what we can and can't address because there's always time and budget attached to it. Unless this game explodes in popularity and makes Rebellion a mint, I can't see them spending loads of time and money fixing it now. So, as far as a recommendation goes; I cannot recommend this game in its current state unfortunately.

Game reminds me of good old Call of Duty 1 and 2. There's not much to tell otherwise, you play as US soldier who is sent on missions against Nazi forces and their allies in Africa, to kill, destroy, gather Intel, etc. Game has some variation of WWll weaponry available, many types of explosives. Visually game looks good, yet nothing special. It's fun 10 hour campaign that you can play with your friend in co-op mode.

content:
Posted: April 23
												A qualified recommendation.  This game felt like a shorter, less interesting revamp of Sniper Elite V2.  Which is weird because Steam says I played 26 hours in SE3 and only 16.8 in SE2.  Maybe it's because I spent so much time in Sniper Elite 3 sneaking around and plinking with my silenced pistol instead of doing what the game is named after.I suppose that's on me.  A lot of the levels suggest a stealthy approach but it's not really necessary.  The AI is pretty bad, so you're expected to kill a few soldiers, move positions, and the survivors will forget you were ever there.  Even if they march across the corpses of their buddies while on patrol.This game takes place in northern Africa so the levels are mostly wide open deserts and generally not that interesting.  I was surprised when the game ended because it wasn't a big spectacular finish, just another dull mission.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												Sniper Elite 3 is a third person tactical shooter developed by Rebellion Developments and published by 505 Games. This game was released on PC, PS3, PS4, 360 and Xbox One in June 2014. It is a prequel to Sniper Elite V2 and the third game in the sniper series. The gameplay in Sniper 3 is based heavily on being slow and steady with your approach to completing objectives, with an also strong focus on sniper gun play much like the previous games. What I really liked about Sniper 3 is that the stealthy approach is pretty much the only viable way to go on most missions otherwise you'll just be pinned down in a firefight and outnumbered. The stealth aspect of the game is done extremely well, you probably will be detected by the enemies whilst taking down the guards, but it is all about cleaning up after yourself by dragging bodies to the long grass, or how you escape and hide away until the enemies give up searching for you. You can use various methods to distract enemies such as throwing rocks and laying traps. Before each level you get to choose your load out, you get the choice of a sniper rifle, a secondary weapon, side arm, and various other items such as grenades, medi-packs and traps. As you level up between stages you also unlock further rewards and items. Of course, a Sniper game wouldn't be complete without the stunning slow motion graphics of your bullet soaring through the air and them piercing through your foes scrotum, this my friends is the pinnacle of slow motion gaming. Granted after a while you'll be skipping them because they will grow tiresome as they play after every kill with your sniper, but still, this gives you a chance to get some brilliant cinematic screenshots to show off your sniping skills. Graphically, Sniper Elite 3 is gorgeous, I wasn't able to push out full graphic settings on 4k resolution, but even on the lower resolutions (1080p), it still looks stunning. There is a wide array of setting to choose from which is always good to see. The visuals are amazing though, the night time levels really show of the games truly stunning lighting effects as well. I was a little disappointed to see the lens flare effect being used a bit too much, but everything else is truly stellar. The game is fully voice acted, with the enemy soldiers speaking in German too, so subtitles are recommended for that. The sound effects really add an extra level of immersion to the gameplay. A nice feature which is added is that you can disguise your bullet shots underneath the sound of loud sounds in game too, which really helps you in your efforts to complete levels as stealthy as possible. I have to admit, this game is quite difficult, even on the easiest settings; you really do need to take each level with a sense of slow and steady. There is really no point in running in all guns blazing because you will just get gunned down within seconds of being spotted. You will need to backtrack plenty of times in order to escape being detected, you'll be needing to hide in rooms, crawl under buildings, anything which you can imagine you doing in the situation you are in, you can do. The latter levels of the game also ramp up the difficulty significantly as well, as each level slowly introduces more and more enemies for you to deal with. Each level in Sniper Elite 3 is massive. Each level will have its own main objective, but as you progress and reach new areas of the zone, you'll also unlock optional objectives, which can be things such as destroying some trucks, cutting off communication or something searching for secret plans. These optional objectives reward you with additional experience at the end of the level and also add an extra element of immersion to the game as well. The size of each level really means that you can get stuck in, and explore to your hearts content. There are countless amounts of collectable items for you to find if that is your thing too. Each of the games objectives, whether it be main or optional, will have more than one way of you being able to complete them, which will really add some replay ability to the game on your second run through. I was a little let down by the fact that I finished the game's single player in about five hours, granted I was playing on the easiest difficulty, but for a big release like this, I was expecting something more to be honest. I can see there being an essence of replay ability due to the nature of the levels being able to be completed in more ways than one, but I would say that there is no real need for playing through the game more than twice at least. There is a multiplayer side to the game, which I tried out, but it seems to be a little on the low side of players, and struggled to actually get into any proper gameplay, because given that it is a sniper based game, most people are camping in well-hidden places just picking people off when they try and complete objectives, for me I didn't really enjoy the multiplayer. Technically, I had a one major problem with Sniper Elite 3, and that was that the game kept crashing on launching the title, it would reach the title screen, but then just crash to desktop. This actually turned out to be an issue with Malwarebytes closing it, so it would be highly recommended that you add the Sniper Elite 3 folder into the exception settings for Malwarebytes if you run that AV. Granted that it wasn't actually Sniper Elite causing the crash, you would still expect the game to have been tested with various popular AVs like this to see if they caused any compatibility problems. My conclusion of Sniper Elite 3 would be that I would only recommend the game as a single player title; because the multiplayer just didn't do it for me. Given that the single player side of the game can be completed in almost five hours, the full price tag of £39, 99 is absolutely absurd, and is actually fairly offensive that they can charge that amount of money for such little content. I would only say this game is worth picking up when it is below the £10 mark, yes the gameplay is top class, and the graphics are stunning, but you can pick up any of the other Sniper games for the same experience in both of those departments for cheaper. Actually saying that, it looks like all of the games in this series are expensive. Definitely wait for sale season to start before adding Sniper Elite 3 to your library.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												The thing I like most about this game is how it's improved since V2. The controls all feel very familiar,  that is to say there's nothing too different about the layout of what-does-what and it's responsive on top of it, even though I still find it a little annoying that you have to take cover behind a crotch-high wall before you can vault over it instead of.. well, -just- vaulting over it. Or perhaps I'm just doing it wrong.You can definitely see that a lot of the effort has gone into the the gory, slow-mo shots where you can see, in close and loving detail, a bullet drill right the way through a poor sod's head, splattering brains, blood and bone everywhere. The only nit-pick I have with it though [honestly, I don't mean to sound like a grim and creepy fellow with this] is that after watching my bullet bore it's way through a man's face and exit with what appears like it should have left a wound the size of a grapefruit, there appears to be little damage to the individual. I've clearly surgically removed several unfortunate blokes' faces with a conservative amount of bullets but when I trot on over to the corpse, those eyes I've taken great care to get rid of are still there. No halves of skull missing or gaping craters where you would assume there'd be a considerable exit wound; kind of makes the gorey, attention to detail of the anatomy side of things feel a little bit half-arsed. But I'll overlook that as it probably is a rather large amount of work to do.Despite this, the game is great fun. Skulking around in the shadows, being able to plan a method of attack from any and all directions instead of the usual, linear path a game can normally give you. Shadows even affect how concealed you are and there are even some lanterns that can be shot to cast a bit more shadow at that; a feature I though V2 desperately needed. The whole relocation mechanic is great as well; forcing you to stay on your toes and not get too comfy in one spot. It adds a bit more of a pace to the game and add a tad more realism to the experience in that a sniper can only take so many shots from the same location, even though realistically a sniper can wait in one spot for days defacating in their pants for even just one good shot.But in all; I do have a couple of huge gripes with this game:We'll start with the length of the game; eight levels stardard just isn't enough for a full price, hyped up title like this. If you know what you're doing you can fly through those levels in less than a day and it's never a good sign when your players get the the end and sigh saying "Is that all?". Also, not including DLC [which I'll get to], four rifles, maching guns and pistols. Really? This game is called -Sniper Elite- and there's only four rifles? What annoys me even more is that the protagonist clearly has a Kar98 on his back in the box art and not only is it not in the game; it's not even DLC. So to even have a nice veriety of guns and even have just more than one thing to do in the survival mode and multiplayer modes you -have- to buy the DLC that came out on day one with the game [and others, now that there's another out I believe]. Why not just include it in the full game? That seems a bit money-grubby to me and like Rebellion has done the fans a bit of a disservice there just make a bit of extra pocket money.However despite the length of the game and the seemingly greedy intentions of having a very limited arsenal included, it's a very solid and very fun game. Definitely worth a go. But to be fair; I wish I didn't spend as much as I did on it for the amount of game I actually got on purchase. A 3.5/5 from me- Matt

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												Pros+ Visually pleasing+ Good UI+ Decent if forgettable voice-work and sound design+ Satisfying sniping mechanics on higher difficulty settingCons- Levels filled with invisible walls- AI is very stupid- Repetative gameplayAt the end of the day, this is not a terrible game. However, the sniper based play is at odds with the stealth. The result is AI that hears booming shots, sees their friends go down, and yet makes no real effort to find the shooter or otherwise respond in any reasonable way.The game feels very dated, and aside from its visuals, it really belongs to 2004 more than 2014. I guess it could be a decent enough distraction if you're really lost for something to play, but there are just way better games out there for the same money.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23
												A qualified recommendation.  This game felt like a shorter, less interesting revamp of Sniper Elite V2.  Which is weird because Steam says I played 26 hours in SE3 and only 16.8 in SE2.  Maybe it's because I spent so much time in Sniper Elite 3 sneaking around and plinking with my silenced pistol instead of doing what the game is named after.I suppose that's on me.  A lot of the levels suggest a stealthy approach but it's not really necessary.  The AI is pretty bad, so you're expected to kill a few soldiers, move positions, and the survivors will forget you were ever there.  Even if they march across the corpses of their buddies while on patrol.This game takes place in northern Africa so the levels are mostly wide open deserts and generally not that interesting.  I was surprised when the game ended because it wasn't a big spectacular finish, just another dull mission.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												The AI in solo mode is terrible.  The bad guys either all have ESP and can hit you from the moment they arrive, or - in lower difficulty modes - they are cardboard targets that stand there and get shot by you.  I can't stand shooter games that have lazy collision modeling.  In other words, if I'm looking down my barrel and have an unobstructed view of my target I should not be bouncing bullets off of the window or ledge I'm looking over.  Also, there is no excuse for a "sandbox" environment that contains uncrossable non-obstacles.  If my guy can jump and climb up a ledge I should not be forced to walk around a 25 cm tall pile of flat steel sheets.  This is one of those games that is frustratingly almost good - but because it's so close it is inexcusable that it would have such glaring 1990's style limitations.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I found this game to be seriously underwhelming. The maps have improved alot since V2 with most of the levels being "open" and expansive but you wil still feel like you get bottlenecked into some situations where there is only one option to progress in the game.On the lower difficulties the AI is as dumb as a bag of gravle and at most they will give you the challange of a cardboard cutout.Vehicles and tanks have the ability to spot you immediately when you exit your hideouts and to me it seems a tad wrong that a enclosed tincan of a tank can spot you faster than a sentry in one of the lookout towers. Slight spoiler ahead : ----------------At one point in the game i have to witness a conversation between three officers to progress along in the game.To trigger this event i had to climb a scaffold and spy on them from above,First time doing this i started climing down the ladder again to get a better vantage point but that resulted in the mission failing.I hate this kind of gamey logic where one wrong step can result in a failed state without any chance of redemtion.----------Personally i found the game to be way too short and it doesn't leave me with the desire to purchase DLC or even replay the game again.Although i give this game a hard time there is some fun to be had and it is a clear upgrade comparing to V2.If i hadn't bought this game i would wait for a sale unless you really really want to play around with thoes XRAY kill shots.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												I thought Rebellion would make improvements to 3, based on their experiences in developing 2. This doesn't appear to be the case, as the game is really rough around the edges, and FEELS hastily thrown together. I haven't seen any bug fixes for single player missions, just multiplayer or co-op play, and that feels kind of crappy. Pretty disappointed in this title, after looking forward to it for so long.My biggest gripes with SE3: Bodies and weapons that float a foot or so off the ground. Firing your rifle at a target and nothing happens. It LOOKS like the weapon fired, SOUNDS like it fired, but you've just shot a round of pixie dust, because you didn't hit anything.Double kills don't occur, no matter HOW perfectly you line up your shot. Long shot? How do you collect THAT?No matter HOW deeply you're in cover, tanks know where you are IMMEDIATELY after one shot, and strafe the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you. Loading screen hints go by so quickly you can't read the damned things.I saved a game, and the next time I opened it, my saved game wasn't there - instead, I found myself getting blown up immediately. Lost all my saved progress and had to start the level over. Enemy AI can apparently see you around corners, and through cover, and will immediately start firing at you, even though you can't see them.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
What I liked: Great Sniping with wind and gravity Brutal X-ray kill cam Fun Stalker-like gameplay if played stealthWhat You Need to Know: Game improves on the stealth from Sniper 2 by giving us indicators on level of detection and makes it oveall just better Has more brutal x ray kill cam XD Allows rifle customization and loadout changes for each mission My biggest complaint was the checkpoints really hurt you with only 2 or 3 checkpoints in the whole game = not alot of fun Had multiple times where the ojbective wouldn't progress and had to restart Had one ojbective that makes you wait for like 3 minutes doing nothing waiting for when your allowed to kill himMy Score:CPrice: Played during free weekendMain reason for quitting: Broken objectives that don't register, and checkpoints that are too spaced outSniper V2 was just more fun and less broken even without the stealth improvements:

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												I remember the time when Sniper Elite V2 was the game I had the most fun with in the series. . . Oh, wait, it still is the most fun in the series. To put it bluntly, Sniper Elite III does nothing to enhance the experience of the player, and falls way too short in what it tried to accomplish. Like, "WOW". I did not see it coming. The many reviews I've read that pointed out that it was  flawed, I didn't think it would be. But, uhh... no. The game sucks.It fails to entertain one with the storyline, the multiplayer, the overall gameplay ... Heck, let's call it Sniper Elite V2.5. I don't see anything new to it, except for the Afrika scenery, and the slightly improved graphics. Which is a tremendous shame.Again, I do like how they have improved the looks of it. The X-Ray shots are now more eye-opening, and the mechanics are more satisfying. But, that's about it. The game was all about the looks. And it only did okay over there. I feel it's an uncomfortable game to go through. It's just ... boring. And I'm NOT so easily bored with 1P-oriented games. So, in conclusion to this tiny review, no, I do not recommend this game. It's mediocre at best.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												EDIT (22.07.2014): Raw mouse input is now available, but the game remains... kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Negative mouse acceleration, wonky alt+tab where it often bugs out, constantly throws you out when you want to tab back into the game, no option to go for windowed mode, very poor npc and character animations that don't really make it fun to follow an NPC with your scope... they just sometimes suddenly stop and turn around without a fluid animation, it is literally just 'teleporting' into different animations, if there is a transition between stances for npcs it's like 1 frame or non-existent.sometimes there's a delay to you clicking and your character actually firing, poorly responsive controls at best.multiplayer is an absolute mess, unplayable.No matter what mode it is, it is a pure camp fest, nonstop, all the time. You move around, you die; you camp in one spot, maybe switch spots after 2-3 kills, you win, no mechanics that give people an incentive to actually move, so can't blame the players. Can't wait for one person to comment "well it is a sniper game, what do you expect?" answer to that: fun gameplay that does not consist of waiting around for seeing a scope glint or seeing something move in the distance after looking out for 3 minutes, which is sometimes very painful to do... thanks to the weird graphical bugs going on with this title, i.e. shadows popping over and under foliage/trees, objects disappearing and fading back in, objects flickering in the distance etc... What else is there to say... ah, yes: If this game did not have cooperative campaign mode it would not be in my possession in the first place, that is literally the only saving grace for this title.however after this title I am convinced that I won't touch any game anymore that has Rebellion listed as a developer, unless they release like an absolute masterpiece which would actually have responsive and snappy controls.Campaign boils down to: shoot twice, move out of the area "which they elegantly call RELOCATING" and move back to the same spot when, for some reason, all the soldiers calmed down again. Rinse & repeat.Really dull game, no fun mechanics, shooting feels awkward and not satisfying either, thanks to the mouse control problems going on. Pretty funny paradox actually, you create a game where your aim, reaction time and positional prediction/knowing how fast your bullet travels is your skill, YET you fail to make the controls feel snappy and responsive, rather the opposite of that, which almost totally eliminates aim and reaction time... so yeah, not a good game. barely decent, and not even worth half the asking price imvho.p.s.: weapon sounds and secondary/tertiary weapon spread behaviour are copied & pasted from Sniper Elite V2, you might just as well go play that.TL;DR: No. The biggest fun you can have in this game is shooting some guy's balls off.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												"World War II Secret Agent Game"Let me start off by saying that "Sniper" should not even be in the title of this game. So little of what you do in this game is what a Sniper actually does, really frustrated me. I have yet to even complete the story of the game because to me it just felt so disconnected, boring and just plain BAD at times. What it really should be called is "OSS Files" or something of the sort, something that clues you in to be more of a Secret Agent who HAPPENS to be a really good marksman, not a US Army Sniper. I've been playing this series from the get go and time and time again I've been disappointed by it. Between the simple fact that a lot of the rifles in this game wouldn't have been used as Sniper Rifles, to the downright horrendous AI even on higher difficulties, leads me to finally write a sadly quite bad review for this game. Now. Let's dive into the Pro/Con.Pros:-Wide variety of tasty WWII-era, mostly authentic weaponry for your Nazi-killing pleasure.-Did I mention variety?-Bullet physics and the like are desperately refeshing in a gaming era dominated by CoD and Battlefield where legitmate ballistics are woefully lacking if existant at all.-The environment is very immersive and authentic, right down to the vehicles.Cons:-Remember that variety I mentioned? Yeah. You have to pay for a lot of it.-The AI ranges from laughably stupid to mind-numbingly difficult.-Remember those physics I was talking about? Yeah. They only work sometimes.-"Remote detonated TNT" that you shoot to set off. (Don't even get me started with the physics of this one)-The lack of any GENUINE sniping got old after the first two or three hours.-No seriously. You BARELY snipe anyone in this game. 100-300 meters does not constitute sniping. I regularly make shots inside that distance with my Iron-sighted rifle at the gun range.-Did I mention stupid AI?-I could go on. No really. I could.Bottom line is, the game can be really, really enjoyable. It also can be the bane of your existance and WILL drive you absolutely insane with how bad some of the story can be. Honestly a very fun game, with sadly tons and tons of unrealized potential, that the game reminds me of every single time I boot it up.

												Good idea, poor execution. Wish I could give this game a "neutral" score, no other game hits that "average" mark so perfectly for me.+ cool kill cams, too bad it's exactly the same thing as in previous releases+ setting choice, African front of WW2 is underused in games- linear, boring levels, for a stealth game way too linear, pretty much only 1 approach per each mission, no alternatives- AI can't ever find the player, doesn't detect when they should, detect when they shouldn't, sucks at combat- game feels too clear, too smooth, it really fails to create an atmosphere for itself- level design! it's so bad it should be mentioned twice to highlight it- bugs, invisible walls/poor hitboxes in a freaking sniping game? Yeah!- cringy main character with zero depth (also - same guy that voices the protagonist in Hatred, put me off it doesn't fit"- dated graphics; I can only run on medium to have decent FPS, but many games such as Far Cry and Battlefield I can run properly with far more graphical fidelity- sounds...for a gamea bout shooting guns they sound pretty mediocre, explosions are especially poorly doneSo no, don't buy it - thanks for free weekend so I was able to check it out and decide it's crap.Made me want to play Far Cry 3 again, to remind myself what a good stealth shooter game is!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Okay so long story short, this game is ♥♥♥♥in amazing. Sure, some things are kind of funky, it is a third person controlled game afterall. But I'll get more into that.Started at 11:30pm. Joined a multiplayer match, not even having touched the gameplay before. Bro came into my room at 12:30pm and said "dude its 12:30, go to bed". It felt like 10 minutes. There wasn't even any voice chat going. Just the intensity and your heart racing in real life and in game as you line up a shot. You spawn. You creep your way to a window that is in a shadow, and you peer out carefully, pulling up your binoculars and scanning the landscape, focusing in on distant points as closer things become blurry because your eyes aren't focusing on it. Everything seems clear, so you climb out the window swiftly and go into a sprint to get to the next shadow. As you hit the side of the building, you are panting heavily, and your heart is racing at 93bmp, making it hard to hear your surroundings. As you catch your breath, you pull out your binoculars again and scan the landscape again. Out the corner of the circlular binoculars, you see a blimpse of movement. You quickly switch back to your scoped M1 Garand and focus in on the air. In the real world your heart is beating faster, and you're focusing more and more on that spot, waiting for your unsuspecting prey to poke their head out. Then you hear a gunshot and a split second later you are falling over, dead.In this time frame about 2 minutes have passed, and it was the most intense, realistically worrying experience you've felt ever playing a video game.Singleplayer is just a ton of fun, using broken generators and artillary barages and planes flying overhead in order to mask your sniper rifle's firing so that the German Afrika Corps soldiers don't realize you're there. Having to figure out the puzzle of who to shoot first and at what point on their patrol so that their buddies don't see the body but also masking the sound of your shot and firing from a position where you aren't visible to enemies. Setting up an ambush with Dynamite and blowing it up to cause mass confusion and win the section of that mission.Oh, I almost forgot, I spent 3 of these hours on the first mission ALONE. Let alone the countless others to come.A game has never made my heart race this hard, or keep me entralled in heart startling multiplayer.I give it a total of 9.5/10, because third person moving is a painnnnnn in the♥♥♥♥♥ I often find myself using my iron sights to walk through some spots because its like using first person controls

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Sniper Elite 3 has provided several new aspects to the Sniper Elite trilogy, making it an excellent sequel, including features such as...- A new "sandbox" type  feel to the game that its predecessors had lacked. - A change of scenery from the typical WW2 shooters taking place in Europe and the Pacific.- A clever (yet primitive) relocation system after every shot.- An awesome class customization system.- Missions that can take up to 2 hours to complete if you attempt to do everything in the game you can.- The multiplayer is still very entertaining, but I would like to warn potential buyers that there are usually only around 13 servers capable of holding 12 players each in session.The Sniper Elite series i have come to enjoy greatly, and SE3 has and continues to provide me with numerous hours of enjoyment, however I simply CAN NOT RECOMMEND  Sniper Elite 3 simply because I am extremely disappointed that the game WAS RELEASED ALONGSIDE $25 WORTH OF DOWNLOADABLE CONTENT. Although the content is basically only aesthetic (in my opinion, the DLC weapons provide little change in gameplay) it still makes me furious. This is content that could have been included into standalone game! TL;DR - Sniper Elite 3 is an excellent sequel to Sniper Elite V2 and provides several new features that make the game more enjoyable than the last, HOWEVER I CAN NOT AND WILL NOT RECOMMEND IT simply to reflect my disappointment that the game was realeased with $25 worth of downloadable content. Beware that there are only roughly 100 people playing multiplayer at a time.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Sniper Elite 3 has provided several new aspects to the Sniper Elite trilogy, making it an excellent sequel, including features such as...- A new "sandbox" type  feel to the game that its predecessors had lacked. - A change of scenery from the typical WW2 shooters taking place in Europe and the Pacific.- A clever (yet primitive) relocation system after every shot.- An awesome class customization system.- Missions that can take up to 2 hours to complete if you attempt to do everything in the game you can.- The multiplayer is still very entertaining, but I would like to warn potential buyers that there are usually only around 13 servers capable of holding 12 players each in session.The Sniper Elite series i have come to enjoy greatly, and SE3 has and continues to provide me with numerous hours of enjoyment, however I simply CAN NOT RECOMMEND  Sniper Elite 3 simply because I am extremely disappointed that the game WAS RELEASED ALONGSIDE $25 WORTH OF DOWNLOADABLE CONTENT. Although the content is basically only aesthetic (in my opinion, the DLC weapons provide little change in gameplay) it still makes me furious. This is content that could have been included into standalone game! TL;DR - Sniper Elite 3 is an excellent sequel to Sniper Elite V2 and provides several new features that make the game more enjoyable than the last, HOWEVER I CAN NOT AND WILL NOT RECOMMEND IT simply to reflect my disappointment that the game was realeased with $25 worth of downloadable content. Beware that there are only roughly 100 people playing multiplayer at a time.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												How Rebellion can charge £40 for this is beyond me. The game is neither finished nor polished. I have experienced xray bullet cams simply not showing up, although the sound does play. Objects such as ammo caches being present but not visible (still usable though). Grey aiming indicator suggesting that there is an obstruction between me and my target when there clearly is not. Invisible walls. Clunky movement in 3rd person. Graphics dont load as quickly as they should when you change from looking at something far away to something much closer (see wolfenstein the new order). A dreadfully small selection of weapons and maps (roughly 4 snipers, 4 side arms and about 6 MP maps). Dont even get me started on the fact that you have to buy DLC to add more weapons. The campaign is a bit short in my opinion. They have completely overdone the xray bullet cams. Almost every single kill you make with a sniper activates it, it is difficult to build up any momentum in the SP when literally every time you shoot somebody you have to endure 3 - 5 second slow mo animation of your kill.On the bright side though, you can shoot peoples testicles off.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Single player: Much, much worse than V2, which I enjoyed. This game was clearly rushed. All of the development budget and time seems to have been spent on making the slow mo x-ray scenes that much more grizzly. Bullet physics are great, but no improvement on V2. The devs mixed poor level design, glitchy environments and clunky character movement to create an expensive mess of obliterated expectations. Don't even buy this if it's on sale.Multi player: Such a disappointment. Tiny community, many of which use the game's unfinished, buggy nature and hacking tools to exploit genuine players. There's no anti cheat initiative and so its no wonder that there isn't a dedicated community. The ability to rule out wind and bullet drop essentially means players must perpetually re-adjust their aim from server to server, trashing any sense of challenge or realism. Some hosts opt for high wind and no drop, others for no wind, drop or glint, others for glint and drop no wind, its impossible to derive any satisfaction from the MP when each server requires a completely different aiming mechanic.  Stick to V2. Better community, greater challenge, no hacks.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game.  I played V2 through 3 times on the PS3, bought the zombies army 2 game for PC and played through solo and with a buddy, all of which was fun fun fun.Sadly, this new incarnation is a real let down for me.  It just feels so lazily thrown together, it's lacking any atmosphere, there's no tension at all and it's SO SO SO very easy.  Even on the hardest settings it's a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ and offers little to no satisfaction for any effort you put in.A highly uninspiring game that feels like Rebellion just copped out and cashed in on the popularity of previous titles.  Such a shame.  As a fan of the franchise I'm frankly gutted.The so many DLC guns which add nothing of any importance, make no differnce to gameplay, and apears to be shameless profiteering.  I'm baffled as to how so many people are recommending this, it's really below par.Just a quick edit to clarify something to those who think a 200m shot is some kind of achievment with a sniper rifle...  Standard military engagement training with a standard rifle is 300m, but can achieve acuracy up to 800m with marksman sights.  M16A2 and an M1 Garand can both be fired accurately up to 500m.  Engagement distances of rifles haven't changed much at all since WW1... Though modern 'sniping' is done mostly at closer ranges due to visibility (or lack thereof), for a game going by the name 'sniper elite' I really wanted to see the opportunity for shots at over 800m.  The all new amazing awesome open maps, however... fail to present such options.3.5/10

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												Sniper Elite 3 is a satisfying combination of stealth that's not irritating and sharpshooting that's not impossibly difficult, alongside interesting missions/maps. I'll admit, I passed over this one a few times because of the pedestrian-sounding name. "It does what it says on the tin." It is, however, a gorgeous, well-crafted game on par with Wolfenstein, with added history and realism, and without the monsters.Only two issues: First, Sniper Elite 3 needs more missions (so did v2). We want to play more, we'd happily pay for more DLC, but there is no more. Second, the co-op system could be more robust. Most nights, we can play through a mission with zero problems. Other nights, we'd get 90% through and boom, our game would end because one of us "disconnected" (not really--we were chatting in Mumble the whole time). What followed was a game that often could not be resumed, and much swearing. That said, co-op mode is still the killer feature for us. Great 2-player fun.If you have a friend, and you both have similar levels of patience (or impatience), add this one to your wishlist or cart right now. It runs great in both Windows 10 and Windows 7 for us.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												This review is ENTIRELY based on CO-op play only!The game is Good- You cannot play it like an action game, take it slow and easy- The game is edged towards sniper shooting therefore, only the sniper gets all the love for customizations- Don't look for realism, it's not meant to be so- Only 8 Missions = Almost 3 hrs or so per mission, DLC's add more- Play co-op, a lot more fun.What's not to like:-- The game is not really well designed for Co-op, if one player dies, the game will start from Last check point, there is no drop in and drop off in the game, also if by chance anyone disconnects, you cannot save the game, but WILL have to play ALL the way from the START. This SUX when you've finished everything but the last objective after a 3 hr mission level.- It is not Assassin's creed, it is not a close quarters stealth game BUT appears to be. The game actually deviates from previous Sniper Elite games in this regard as more often than not, you'll actually be taking enemies down with your silenced pistol close up.- Close quarters is clunky, use silenced pistol instead as NOT ALL situations lend to taking silent take-downs, this is by design and incredibly silly as it's not intuitive.- One shot from the sniper gun and the ENTIRE base is almost on you.- Far too much emphasis on Sniper gun only, everything and the kitchen sink is thrown into it, other guns' accuracy and damage is purposely kept lower.- Far too much emphasis on Headshots to take down, seriously! Come on. Give extra XP for it, Don't make a player shoot twice just cause he hit at the torso.- Every mission becomes tediously long of about 3 hrs if you play it slow and hidden in the game.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Sniper Elite 3 is a fun casual sniper game.  I'm giving it a thumbs up because by itself its an alright game.  However that said, I'd like to point out that in my opinion this game is a step back from Sniper Elite v2.  Here's how the two compare in my opinion:Improvements:- less linear maps- improved graphics- more customizable weaponsCons:- Empty lung ability now shows where to aim to adjust for gravity and wind (even on the hardest difficulty).  Sniper Elite v2 is incredibly fun when you get dialed in to a rifle and pull of numerous long range consecutive headshots.  You'll do that in SE3 as well, but it'll be so easy you won't even notice.- The new detection mechanics are broken. While SEv2's were admittedly pretty simple SE3's is just to wonky to ignore.  Get caught in your sniping nest?  No worries, walk 50 meters away, then walk back and the Nazis will forget all about where you've been picking them off from for the past 10 minutes.- Poor clipping on cover.  It's always annoying when you shoot the barrier in front of you when your scope shows a clear shot, but this is especially bad in SE3 where the detection mechanism penalizes you for every shot.- Poor checkpoint system.  Sometimes it saves after objectives, sometimes it saves when you're sitting in a bush, and sometimes it doesn't save at all.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												This review is ENTIRELY based on CO-op play only!The game is Good- You cannot play it like an action game, take it slow and easy- The game is edged towards sniper shooting therefore, only the sniper gets all the love for customizations- Don't look for realism, it's not meant to be so- Only 8 Missions = Almost 3 hrs or so per mission, DLC's add more- Play co-op, a lot more fun.What's not to like:-- The game is not really well designed for Co-op, if one player dies, the game will start from Last check point, there is no drop in and drop off in the game, also if by chance anyone disconnects, you cannot save the game, but WILL have to play ALL the way from the START. This SUX when you've finished everything but the last objective after a 3 hr mission level.- It is not Assassin's creed, it is not a close quarters stealth game BUT appears to be. The game actually deviates from previous Sniper Elite games in this regard as more often than not, you'll actually be taking enemies down with your silenced pistol close up.- Close quarters is clunky, use silenced pistol instead as NOT ALL situations lend to taking silent take-downs, this is by design and incredibly silly as it's not intuitive.- One shot from the sniper gun and the ENTIRE base is almost on you.- Far too much emphasis on Sniper gun only, everything and the kitchen sink is thrown into it, other guns' accuracy and damage is purposely kept lower.- Far too much emphasis on Headshots to take down, seriously! Come on. Give extra XP for it, Don't make a player shoot twice just cause he hit at the torso.- Every mission becomes tediously long of about 3 hrs if you play it slow and hidden in the game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game.  I played V2 through 3 times on the PS3, bought the zombies army 2 game for PC and played through solo and with a buddy, all of which was fun fun fun.Sadly, this new incarnation is a real let down for me.  It just feels so lazily thrown together, it's lacking any atmosphere, there's no tension at all and it's SO SO SO very easy.  Even on the hardest settings it's a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ and offers little to no satisfaction for any effort you put in.A highly uninspiring game that feels like Rebellion just copped out and cashed in on the popularity of previous titles.  Such a shame.  As a fan of the franchise I'm frankly gutted.The so many DLC guns which add nothing of any importance, make no differnce to gameplay, and apears to be shameless profiteering.  I'm baffled as to how so many people are recommending this, it's really below par.Just a quick edit to clarify something to those who think a 200m shot is some kind of achievment with a sniper rifle...  Standard military engagement training with a standard rifle is 300m, but can achieve acuracy up to 800m with marksman sights.  M16A2 and an M1 Garand can both be fired accurately up to 500m.  Engagement distances of rifles haven't changed much at all since WW1... Though modern 'sniping' is done mostly at closer ranges due to visibility (or lack thereof), for a game going by the name 'sniper elite' I really wanted to see the opportunity for shots at over 800m.  The all new amazing awesome open maps, however... fail to present such options.3.5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												So I picked this game up durring the steam summer sale, thinking it would be a nice expierence.It was... but not for the hefty real price tag.The game itself barely has any content right from the start. From missions to guns, there was very little. It seemed to be buy dlc to use this gun type of game. It seemed that the game was aimed for multiplayer.Second issue, clipping. Usually you think you can fire over cover? Wrong. Most cover was broken in the way that the hitbox was larger than your crouch profile; which ended up fluffing your shots. In this game firing alerts enemys to your position so It is frustrating seeing your shot magicaly not happen and you pressing down the trigger agian thinking it just "missed".Third issue, "Sniper Elite". You'd think this game was about sniping, from doing cool trick shots or raining death from afar. You are wrong. Most of the game play is geared towards "stealth". Which means you rarely get to fire your sniper. Firing your gun, ANYWHERE, even if there are no enemies around alerts everyone on the map. Utilizing the system of sound masking, gives you an average of 1 shot per minute, unless you find a generator in a good position which is not common. If you break stealth, depening on the difficulty, all the enemies will come alive and chase you down.Fourth Issue, movement. Sprinting in this game is completly redudant. Normal walking is basicly sprinting without holding shift. Because of this enemies will notice you from afar if you just stand up. This leads to the ENTIRE game of playing CROUCH MAN. Which is completly irratating due to the fact it is slower than a slug. There is no sprint crouch like in MGSV.In the end I rate this game a 6/10. It has a decent engine, mechanics but lacking in content and riddled with bugs and poor in-game player optimization.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												I regret buying this game even on sale. The whole X-ray cam on snipe hit is awesome, but it gets old fast.  The rest of the game is like an advanced version of whack a mole. Enemy pops up, shoot, move to next position, repeat untill next objective, do that for the next couple hours and the game is over.Enemies patrol faster then you can really set up a viable trap, if you try to trigger them to go through it by alarming them they rarely go very far from their patrol pattern so your lucky if you can get a kill that way. If you play on hardest difficulty, you will find it isn't a challenge, but more of a guessing game where your bullets will go, as the game gives no clue where the drift will be, a guess to how far the enemy is, and finding where a missed bullet even went can be tricky.On top of all this, the game is designed focusing on stealth and tactics, but you will find there is not only no motivation in a lot of parts to be stealthy, it is actually easier just to run in guns blazing, and there is no reprecussions to that as the game has absolutely no reward for being stealthy, other then to add hours onto game play of watching your guy crawl through areas of the map.

												PLayed the game for about 10 minutes on hard difficulty. Super dramatic introduction that places you in the middle of action? Check.Natural shake on scope? Check.Wind factor influencing projectile direction? Check.Interesting heart beat mechanic influencing scope steadiness based on stress? Check.Everything great so far, except:HUGE♥♥♥♥♥MARKER ON EVERY ENEMY'S  HEAD, ON EVERY OBJECTIVE, BOTH IN VIEW AND ON MINIMAP? F***** CHECKWhat's the point of making a stealthy sniper game if you mark every enemy with a big "LOOK HERE'S OVER HERE!" symbol that you cannot disable in options? Really? Where's the challenge? Why does my character bother to carry binoculars when he is a telepathic wizard who knows where all his foes are hiding?I instantly dropped the game and uninstalled it. Buyer's remorse. Now, Project I.G.I... now THERE'S a proper sniper game. That old grandfather of sniper games released in 2000 is still far more immersive than this♥♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
 Sniper Elite 3 - A solid WW2 Sniper Game that considering that it launched more then two years ago, still belongs to the best in it`s genre.Considering that Sniper Elite 3 from Rebellion was developed during the peak of the last generation of consoles (PS3/Xbox 360) and therefore had a few limitations brought with it when it launched back in 2014 I`m was very suprised that it still turned into is a solid WW2 Sniper Game with a couple positive aspects and only a tiny among of downs.After the first six hours of Gameplay in which I had played through the first five missions it became clear to me that the biggest advantage of Sniper Elite 3 (compared to it`s very successful predecessor) was also somehow it`s biggest strength - At any point in the Game I could change my play style from being just the skilled Sniper to become the Hand-to-Hand Combat Expert I always wanted to become in Sniper Elite V2 but really couldn't back then for whatever reason.As a Sniper you are as deadly as it can be…It took me the first two mission to realize that I wouldn’t have enough ammunition with me to just blast through the hole Game and so I stopped shooting everyone that run across my sight and instead choose very carefully when and how I would kill someone to not waste my time or my few bullets to many times and instead only kill those that i coudn’t avoid to get past through or if I couldn`t kill those in a more effective way with what the Developers of Rebellion had put on the Map for me that I could use to kill someone instead.In my eyes one of the biggest strengths of Sniper Elite 3 is that you can`t only shoot everyone but that the Game does allow you from time to time in the Game too to use different ways to get right of your enemies in a more effective way if you look out for those hints that the developer might have left for you on the map.…but you will never have brought enough ammunition with you to kill everyone on the field so choose carefully whom you shoot…Secondly the Maps are as always great and always fit the hole African Corps theme very much and I have encountered more then once a moment in the Game where I just stopped moving and enjoyed the overall design and architecture. …since otherwise you might regret it in the end if you waste your last bullet on someone that wasn’t worth your time and your bullet.On the other hand I can clearly understand why some wouldn’t enjoy playing such a game that would force to to first think before they shoot and instead scout first a (complete) map out and afterwards plan how they would have to proceed from there on to full fill their different mission goals from there on. This is also so far my major issue with the Game. Instead of trying to offer those that want to blast through the hole Map and blow everything up enough ammunition the Game so far made it clear to me that it don`t want to bend enough for those kind of Gamers but instead want to put those in a corset and teach them to slow down too many time. Some will like that while others won’t.Conclusion:I haven`t yet finished playing through the Game so far but I’ll for sure play through the other left missions over the upcoming Christmas Holidays and update my Review of the Game with more Details about the Single Player Mode and a couple of Multiplayer Games too if I will encounter more issues with the Game.But seeing how much I have enjoyed playing Sniper Elite 3 till today I would definitely give the Game a strong…Thumbs Up.That´s it. Thanks for reading and have a great time ;-)

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Con:- Poor control due to bad 3rd person implementation. A scrolling option like in Skyrim would be good. It is extremely hard to maneuver inside a building or between cover-sandbags. And you can barely estimate if your choosen cover will hide you from getting spotted.- When you aim 1st person you will likely hit an obstructing object (door frame, window).- There is no such thing as tactics because you can not always choose your path. No free movement.- 99% of the fights take place in almost cqb (50m). That is not sniping!- DCLs (= Did not finish game / want more money). But that is a common probleme these days.Pro:- Nice graphics and lighting- Runnes smooth on GTX770Maybe the developer should not have focused on "Revamped human X-Ray Kill cam". Was good in SE2 anyway.
